Tanks entered Tremseh after forces had shelled the town continuously from 5 a.m. until noon. Syrian army forces, whose numbers were bolstered by "Shabeha", accompanied the tanks into Tremseh.{{cite news|title=Syrian opposition reports 'massacre' in Hama province|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/07/12/world/meast/syria-unrest/index.html?hpt=hp_t2|publisher=CNN|accessdate=15 July 2012|author=CNN Wire Staff|date=13 July 2012}} ''See also: [[Battle of Tremseh]].'' |- |Outside listed towns in [[Hama Governorate|Hama G.]] | |— |r[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]]97%[[File:Syria-flag 1932-58 1961-63.svg|40px]][[File:Flag of Hayat Tahrir al-Sham.svg|40px]]3% |{{anchor|Others Hama}}[[File:2013 Hama Offensive.svg|250px|thumb|right|Frontlines in the Hama Governorate during the [[2013 Hama offensive]].{{leftlegend|#EDC4BE|Syrian Government control}} {{leftlegend|#CDEBC9|Opposition control}} {{leftlegend|#B6A25F|Contested}}]]By June 2012, [[Free Syrian Army|FSA]] controlled swathes of land in Northern Hama governorate. FSA and local people, administered justice and the distribution of supplies to residents.[http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/06/07/2837890/in-northern-syria-rebels-now-control.html]{{dead link|date=December 2015}} On 16 December 2012, the Syrian armed opposition launched the [[2012 Hama offensive]] with the intent of taking control of Hama Governorate. Within two days, the [[Syrian Observatory for Human Rights]] claimed that government troops had already been cleared from the towns of [[Hasraya]], and Sheikh Hadid.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/310435475731464|title=Hama Province|last=SOHR|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=19 December 2012}} Rebels had advanced {{convert|40|km|mi}} south from [[#Maarrat al-Nu'man|Maarrat al-Nu'man]] and [[#Jisr ash-Shugour|Jisr ash-Shugour]], encountering little resistance.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/middle-east-live/2012/dec/18/syria-conflict-kidnappings-yarmouk-camp-damascus-live#block-50d08c71b5793fbbacbc4f40|title=Rebel gains (3.32pm GMT)|date=18 December 2012|work=Middle East Liveblog|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=19 December 2012|location=London|first=Matthew|last=Weaver}} {{anchor|Kafr Zita}}On 19 December, brigades of FSA claimed in videos that they had captured [[Kafr Zita]] and all area north of Hama city. It seemed that rebels had overrun the loyalist army lines north of Hama city within 48 hours{{cite web|url=http://www.enduringamerica.com/home/2012/12/18/syria-live-coverage-a-battle-for-hama.html|title=EA WorldView - Home - Syria Live Coverage: A Battle for Hama?|publisher=|accessdate=25 October 2014}} On 20 December, rebel commander Kassem Saaddedin said via Skype that rebels had captured six towns north of Hama. He claimed FSA controlled Kafr Zita, and Hasraya.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.com/topic/syria/syrian-rebels-take-control-several-districts-hama|title=Syrian rebels take control of several districts in Hama|work=Al Jazeera Blogs|accessdate=25 October 2014}} In April 2013, Syrian rebels launched [[2013 Hama offensive|a military operation]] in the eastern part of the province of Hama, in an attempt to open up a new front, after rebel attacks in the governorate had stalled. The rebels managed to capture 10 villages during their offensive. However, the Army soon captured 20–23 villages, including most of the ones previously captured by the rebels. {{anchor|iswhama}}On 7 September 2013, it was reported that there were many checkpoints manned by Assad’s forces in northwestern Hama province. ISIS also controls some parts of Hama countryside.{{citation |mode=cs1 |date=7 September 2013 |title=A Video Tour of Regime Checkpoints in Hama Province |url=http://iswsyria.blogspot.fr/2013/09/a-video-tour-of-regime-checkpoints-in.html |publisher=Institute for the Study of War |accessdate=19 May 2014 }} ''See also: [[2013 Hama offensive]].'' During the middle of 2014, rebels launched an attack toward Hama City and Hama military airport. During this offensive, they seized several villages, but the Syrian military quickly launched a counter attack, reversing all rebels gains and taking new villages. As of October 2014, in Northern Hama, rebels are in control of only a few villages near the Idlib governorate. On 5 October 2017, the Syrian army recaptured the all area which was under control Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant in Hama province.{{cite web|url=https://muraselon.com/en/2017/10/map-update-syrian-army-clears-isis-enclave-east-hama/|title=Map Update: Syrian Army clears out ISIS enclave in east Hama - Muraselon|date=4 October 2017|publisher=|accessdate=4 February 2018}} |} ==al-Hasakah Governorate== {| class="toccolours sortable" border="1" cellpadding="3" style="border-collapse:collapse" |+ |- style="background:lavender;" !Name !Population ![[Districts of Syria|District]] !Held by !History of the [[Syrian Civil War]] |- |[[Al-Hasakah]] |188,160 |[[Al-Hasakah District]] |q[[File:Ala kurdên rojava.svg|40px]]95%{{cite web|url=http://aranews.net/2016/08/kurds-triumph-in-battle-against-syrian-regime/|title=Kurds triumph in battle against Syrian regime - ARA News|date=24 August 2016|publisher=|accessdate=27 July 2017}}[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]]5% |''See [[Al-Hasakah#Syrian Civil War|Al-Hasakah (Syrian Civil War)]].'' |- |[[Qamishli]] |184,231 |[[Qamishli District]] |q[[File:Ala kurdên rojava.svg|40px]][[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Qamishli}}In July 2012, rebels control the suburbs of the city. On 21 July, the rebels were intending to capture the largest of the Kurdish cities.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/07/21/world/meast/syria-unrest/index.html?hpt=hp_t2 |title=Ban: Syrian regime 'failed to protect civilians' |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date= 22 July 2012|accessdate=29 August 2013}} On 22 July, clashes erupted between [[Popular Protection Units|YPG]] and government forces in which one Kurdish fighter was killed and two were wounded along with one government official.{{cite web|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/news/syria/4984.html |title=Armed Kurds Surround Syrian Security Forces in Qamishli |publisher=Rudaw.net |date= |accessdate=29 August 2013}} In early August 2012, it was reported that the Assad administration is intact and functioning but the police and army remain in their barracks. Kurds in Qamishli have demonstrated against the Government and are actually allowed to do so on one street, though some have been shot at by the army in the past. There is a border post near the city.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wKGos2QgaDg Kurds push for future in post-Assad era], Al Jazeera English. As of 18 December 2013, the regime controls about 10 percent of Qamishli, including the airport, the security quarter housing the intelligence services, and several buildings to the south. Regime security services move unfettered around the city and the surrounding Arab villages. In many ways, the PYD is neutral in the civil war, because they see it as a war between two evils. Even so, the YPG has sporadically skirmished with regime units for control of checkpoints.[http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/the-fractious-politics-of-syrias-kurds, December 18, 2013]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Syrian regime retains wide control in city of Qamishli.{{cite news|title=Armed groups, regime fight for control of eastern Syria |url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/security/2014/02/syria-eastern-region-harsh-front.html|publisher=Al Monitor|date=5 February 2014|author=Tareq al-Abed}} In February 2014, a Human Rights Watch official explained that the Assad forces and the government is basically present in three places in Qamishli: One is in the center so they call it kind of ‘security square.’ That also includes some Arab neighborhoods. The second is on the Turkish border at the border crossing. The third is at the airport.{{cite news|title=Rights Official Speaks of Situation in Rojava, PYD Challenges |url=http://rudaw.net/english/interview/02032014|publisher=Rudaw|date=2 March 2014|author=MUTLU CIVIROGLU}} ''See also: [[2012 Syrian Kurdistan campaign]].'' |- |[[Ras al-Ayn, al-Hasakah|Ras al-Ayn]] |29,347 |[[Ra's al-'Ayn District]] |v[[File:Ala kurdên rojava.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Ras al-Ayn}}''See [[Ras al-Ayn, al-Hasakah Governorate#Syrian Civil War|Ras al-Ayn (Syrian Civil War)]].'' |- |[[Al-Malikiyah]] |26,311 |[[Al-Malikiyah District]] |v[[File:Ala kurdên rojava.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Al-Malikiyah}}''See [[Al-Malikiyah#Syrian Civil War|Al-Malikiyah (Syrian Civil War)]].'' |- |[[Qamishli Border Crossing]] |— |[[Qamishli District]] |v[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Qamishli Border Crossing}}By late November 2013, the border crossing between [[Qamishli]] and the Turkish city of [[Nusaybin]] was controlled by the Syrian government.{{cite news|title=Syria-Turkey Border Crossing to Reopen This Week, Officials Say |url=http://rudaw.net/english/middleeast/syria/30112013|publisher=[[Rudaw]]|date=30 November 2013|accessdate=4 December 2013}} |- |[[Simalka Border Crossing]] |— |[[Al-Malikiyah District]] |v[[File:Ala kurdên rojava.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Simalka}}Border crossing between towns of Simalka on Syrian side and Fish Khabur on [[Iraq]]i side was built by Iraqi [[Kurdistan Regional Government]] in order to connect [[Iraqi Kurdistan]] with Syrian Kurdish regions. Border crossing is actually only a temporary military bridge over river [[Tigris]] hoisted by [[Peshmerga]] to facilitate transfer of goods and refugees which was opened on 1 February 2013. Since 1991 it was used only by boats and after 2003 it was not used in order to promote Rabia land border crossing.{{cite web|url=http://www.alsumaria.tv/news/70954/a-new-commercial-crossing-point-opens-between-iraq/en|title=A new commercial crossing point opens between Iraq Kurdistan and Syria|publisher=|accessdate=25 October 2014}} |- |Outside listed towns in [[Al-Hasakah Governorate|Al-Hasakah G.]] | |— |q[[File:Flag of Syrian Democratic Forces.svg|40px]]95%[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]]5% |{{anchor|Others al-Hasakah}}[[File:The Situation in Hasakah.svg|250px|thumb|right|Territories held by Kurdish forces, ISIL jihadists, by the Syrian Army or contested in the Al-Hasakah Province, as of 23 March 2016]] On 8 January 2013, [[Free Syrian Army|FSA]] took control of Tishreen oil field. Opposition sources reported that all other oil fields in the governorate were under Syrian government control.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oxp9be1hoCs |title=هاتفيا مصطفى الحسن ناشط إعلامي الرقة. |publisher=Syria Tomorrow |date=8 January 2013 |accessdate=8 January 2013}} ''See also: [[2012 Syrian Kurdistan campaign]].'' |} ==Homs Governorate== {| class="toccolours sortable" border="1" cellpadding="3" style="border-collapse:collapse" |+ |- style="background:lavender;" !Name !Population ![[Districts of Syria|District]] !Held by !History during the [[Syrian Civil War]] |- |[[Homs]] - Abbasiya |33,363 |[[Homs District]] |n[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Homs}}{{anchor|Abbasiya}} |- |[[Homs]] - Baba Amr |34,175 |[[Homs District]] |n[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Baba Amr}}On 28 February 2012, reinforcements from [[4th Armoured Division (Syria)]], directed by the [[Maher al-Assad]], brother of the Syrian president, took positions in Homs. They managed to completely seal off the city, notably by destroying a tunnel.{{cite web |url=http://www.nowlebanon.com/NewsArchiveDetails.aspx?ID=370304 |title=Syria sends elite troops to Homs, activists say |date=28 February 2012 |work=NOW Lebanon |accessdate=21 April 2012}} On the morning of 29 February, the [[Syrian Army]] launched a ground assault with infantry on the rebel-held district.{{cite news| url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/02/29/syria-idINDEE81Q0AS20120229 | work=Reuters | title=Pray for us' say Syria rebels as army closes in | date=29 February 2012 |accessdate=21 April 2012 |author=Khaled Yacoub Oweis}} On 1 March 2012, the Syrian Army [[Siege of Homs#Fall of Baba Amr|took full control of the quarter of Baba Amr]] according to a Syrian official. Rebel leaders reported that they pulled out of the quarter and that some fighters stayed to cover the retreat.{{cite web |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/03/01/197926.html |title=Syrian National Council forms military body; rebels pull out of Baba Amro |date=1 March 2012 |publisher=Al Arabiya News |accessdate=21 April 2012}} On 3 July 2012, clashes raged in and around the neighborhood of Baba Amr.{{cite web |url=http://www.arabtimesonline.com/NewsDetails/tabid/96/smid/414/ArticleID/185217/reftab/36/t/Troops-pound-Homs-48-killed/Default.aspx|title=Troops pound Homs, 48 killed |date=3 July 2012 |publisher=Arab times |accessdate=19 August 2012}} On 10 March 2013, rebel fighters launched an assault on the district, around a year after its capture by government troops, in an effort to relieve pressure on besieged rebel-held districts in the city centre.{{cite news|last=Yacoub |first=Khaled |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/03/10/uk-syria-crisis-homs-idUKBRE9290BV20130310?i=5 |title=Syrian rebel fighters break through Homs siege - opposition |publisher=Uk.reuters.com |date=10 March 2013 |accessdate=29 August 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/clashes-erupt-flashpoint-syrian-district-18699897 |title=Syria Regime Targets Flashpoint Homs Neighborhood |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date=24 August 2013 |accessdate=29 August 2013}} However, the military re-secured the district and repelled the rebels two weeks later.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/03/26/us-syria-crisis-homs-idUSBRE92P07U20130326 |title=Syrian army recaptures symbolic Baba Amr district in Homs |publisher=Reuters.com |date= 26 March 2013|accessdate=29 August 2013 |first=Erika |last=Solomon}} |- |[[Homs]] – [[Deir Baalbah]] |44,795 |[[Homs District]] |n[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Deir Baalbah}}In October 2012, [[Free Syrian Army|FSA]] took over part of the neighborhood that has been under army control for many months. The government is encouraging former inhabitants to return.{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/districts-abandoned-in-syrias-blitzed-city-9f8zw8x85|title=Capital of Syria’s revolution is a ghost city|first=Tom Coghlan,|last=Homs|publisher=|accessdate=27 July 2017}} Activists reported that up to 200 civilians were killed in the assault.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20869448|title=Syria government forces retake Homs district|last=Corera|first=Gordon|date=30 December 2012|publisher=BBC|accessdate=30 December 2012}} |- |[[Homs]] - Joret al-Shayyah |16,816 |[[Homs District]] |r[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Joret al-Shayyah}}On 3 July 2012, the military made an attempt to storm Joret al-Shayyah.[http://www.france24.com/en/20120703-syria-troops-pound-homs-watchdog Syria troops pound Homs: watchdog] {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/8/47475/World/Region/Clashes-in-Damascus,-at-least--dead-in-Syria-NGO-.aspx |title=Clashes in Damascus, at least 52 dead in Syria: NGO |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=11 July 2012 |accessdate=29 August 2013}} On 5 October 2012, Syrian warplanes and artillery pounded Joret al-Shayyah, subjecting it to its worst bombardment in months. However, rebels still hold the suburb. |- |[[Homs]] – al-Waer | |[[Homs District]] |r[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|al-Waer}} On March 2017 rebels fighters agreed with Syrian officials a withdraw from al-Waer to al-Bab in Idlib Governorate.{{cite web|url=http://www.syriahr.com/en/?p=63129|title=Migrants convoy reach Idlib after leaving al-Waer neighborhood|publisher=|accessdate=26 May 2017}} |- |[[Homs]] |353,184 |[[Homs District]] |p[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Other neighborhoods Homs}}[[File:Siege of Homs Map.svg|thumb|right|250px|Situation in Homs as of May 2014]] January 2012 saw intense fighting in the opposition stronghold of Homs, as the opposition claimed to be in control of ⅔ of the city. However, starting on 3 February 2012, the [[Syrian army]] launched a major offensive to take rebel-held neighborhoods in the city. By the end of March, and after weeks of artillery bombardments and heavy street fighting, the Syrian army retakes control of half a dozen districts, leaving them in control of 70 percent of the city. By March 2013, the military was in control of 80 percent of the city.{{cite web|author=AFP |url=http://www.livemint.com/Politics/XQ3WDSAoRSitfoGX5OYFpM/Syria-military-pounds-Homs-for-fourth-day-watchdog.html |title=Syria military pounds Homs for fourth day: watchdog |publisher=Livemint.com |date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=29 August 2013}} On 7 May, under the terms of the agreement between the Syrian government and rebels the government forces take over all rebels districts in Homs city and Al Waer district in western Homs city.{{cite web|url=http://live.aljazeera.com/Event/Syria_Live_Blog/115191327|title=The ceasefire deal|work=AJE Live Events|accessdate=25 October 2014}}{{cite web|author=AFP |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/05/fighters-begin-withdrawal-from-syria-homs-20145773755680799.html |title= Fighters begin withdrawal from Syria's Homs |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=7 May 2014}} ''See also: [[Siege of Homs]] and [[2012 Homs offensive]].'' |- |[[Al-Mukharram]] |6,202 |[[Al-Mukharram District]] |n[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Al-Mukharram}}Al-Mukharram and the localities of its district have a significant [[Alawite]] population.{{cite book|first=Hanna|last=Batatu|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Mbr-ZfU_uCoC&dq=Bayt+Yashut&source=gbs_navlinks_s|title=Syria's Peasantry, the Descendants of Its Lesser Rural Notables, and Their Politics|publisher=Princeton University Press|year=1999|isbn=0691002541}}, p. 154 and pp. 185-186. The government has maintained control. |- |[[Palmyra (modern)|Palmyra]] |51,323 |[[Palmyra District]] |n[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Palmyra}}''See [[Palmyra#Syrian Civil War|Palmyra (Syrian Civil War)]].'' |- |[[Al-Qusayr, Syria|Al-Qusayr]] |29,818 |[[Al-Qusayr District]] ||n[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Al-Qusayr}}Al-Qusayr, which lies along the Lebanese border, is a critical node in rebel supply lines that links the predominantly [[Sunni]] areas of Lebanon’s northern Bekaa valley. Rebels had been fighting loyalist troops in the border town long before the survivors of the [[Farouq Brigades]] arrived, but in the second half of March, fighting in al-Qusayr picked up. Rebels and loyalist troops had reached an uneasy stalemate in the city by the time the ceasefire went into effect in mid-April, since neither side had been able to expel the other from the town, but by the end of May, the pace of fighting had picked up again and gun battles raged two out of every three days in al-Qusayr On 10 July 2012, Al-Qusayr was completely under rebel control with the city being under siege from the surrounding countryside.{{cite web|author=AFP |url=http://dawn.com/2012/07/10/syrias-qusayr-prepares-for-ramadan-under-siege/ |title=Qusayr prepares for Ramandan under siege |publisher=Dawn.com |date=10 July 2012 |accessdate=29 August 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q23i8ien92M |title=Surviving a Siege - Syria |publisher=Youtube.com |date=24 September 2012 |accessdate=29 August 2013}} However, later, it was confirmed that government troops still held the town's main road.{{cite news|last=Blomfield |first=Adrian |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/9582662/Hizbollah-mourns-its-dead-from-Syrian-fighting.html |title=Hizbollah mourns its dead from Syrian fighting |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date= 2 October 2012|accessdate=29 August 2013 |location=London}} On 5 June it was confirmed that government troops were if full control of Al-Qusayr {{cite news|author=Jacob Wirtschafter, Special for USA TODAY |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2013/06/05/syrian-tv-army-in-control-of-key-town-of-qusair/2390947/ |title=Key Syria town of al-Qusayr falls to government troops |publisher=Usatoday.com |date=5 June 2013 |accessdate=29 August 2013}} See also: [[Battle of al-Qusayr (2013)|Battle of Al-Qusayr]] and [[Al-Qusayr offensive]].'' |- |[[Al-Rastan]] |39,834 |[[Ar-Rastan District]] ||n[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Al-Rastan}}Al-Rastan is on the main highway between [[Damascus]] and [[Aleppo]]. The area near Al-Rastan was scene of the first serious armed confrontations between army defectors and loyalist forces through 2011.[http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/05/14/214012.html "EU agrees new Syria sanctions; clashes kill 23 troops amid fresh scuffles in Lebanon"], al-Arabiya. Assad’s forces regained control of the city several times, but it has kept slipping back into rebel hands. Its strategic location along the road which links the capital Damascus to the north of the country{{cite web |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20120611-2012-06-11-2049-wb-en-webnews |title=Syria: army intensifies attack on Rastan |publisher=FRANCE 24 |date=24 August 2013 |accessdate=29 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141025185640/http://www.france24.com/en/20120611-2012-06-11-2049-wb-en-webnews/ |archivedate=25 October 2014 |df= }} and the terrain had helped deserters from disparate units mount raids against Syrian army buses and roadblocks manned by Military Intelligence and pro-Assad militia. (''see also: [[Siege of Rastan and Talbiseh]], [[Battle of Rastan, 2011]] and [[Battle of Rastan, 2012]]''). The rebels in Al-Rastan were strong enough to fend off a [[May 2012 battle of Rastan|military offensive in mid-May 2012]]. After twelve hours of indirect fire to soften rebel positions, elite security forces assaulted Al-Rastan in armored vehicles. The rebels destroyed three armored vehicles, including a main battle tank, and killed over twenty government troops. The rebels had their own losses, including a long-standing leader within Khalid bin Walid and its affiliated units, Lieutenant Ahmad Ayoub. The Army called off the assault and retreated to the perimeter to shell the city with rockets through the following day. Ten days later security forces attempted another combined arms assault on the rebel stronghold, failed again, and took similar heavy losses. The two main rebel forces in the Homs area, the Khaled Ibn Walid Brigade and [[Farouq Brigades|Farouq]], both work out of Rastan[http://www.economist.com/node/21560919?fsrc=scn/tw_ec/more_than_they_can_chew "More than they can chew"], economist, 25 August 2012. |- |[[Taldou]] |15,727 |[[Taldou District]] ||n[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Taldou}}''See [[Taldou#civilwar|Taldou (Syrian Civil War)]].'' |- |[[Talkalakh]] |18,412 |[[Talkalakh District]] |y[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Talkalakh}}On 15 May 2011, the [[Military of Syria|Syrian military]] [[May 2011 Talkalakh siege|entered the town]] which is on the border with [[Lebanon]], in a crackdown against pro-democracy protesters.{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/node/102843/section/6 |title="We Live as in War" | Human Rights Watch |publisher=Hrw.org |date=11 November 2011 |accessdate=29 August 2013}} There followed reports that the military was massacring members of the Syrian opposition. The reports were mostly from civilians fleeing over the Kabir River into Lebanon to escape the violence.{{cite web|url=http://www.yalibnan.com/2011/05/15/at-least-7-protesters-killed-by-syrian-army-in-tall-kalakh/ |title=At least 7 protesters killed by Syrian army in Tall Kalakh |location=LB |publisher=Yalibnan.com |date=15 May 2011 |accessdate=29 August 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.yalibnan.com/2011/05/27/syrian-refugees-cross-lebanon-border-to-escape-massacre/ |title=Syrian refugees cross Lebanon border to escape massacre |location=LB |publisher=Yalibnan.com |date=27 May 2011 |accessdate=29 August 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nowlebanon.com/NewsArchiveDetails.aspx?ID=272327 |title=Syrian security forces kill "at least eight" in Talkalakh |publisher=Nowlebanon.com |date=4 March 2013 |accessdate=29 August 2013}} By 19 May, the military finished its operation and withdrew from Talkalakh.[http://www.nowlebanon.com/NewsArchiveDetails.aspx?ID=272750 Syrian troops withdraw from Talkalakh, witness says]. nowlebanon Since June 2012, [[Free Syrian Army|FSA]] has controlled some neighbourhoods of the city, however the government has retained control of loyalist and mixed neighbourhoods.{{cite news|title=Returning People of TalKalakh: Our City Is a Gate for Inevitable Death from Border. |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-302269137.html |publisher=Syrian Arab News Agency (SANA) |date=12 September 2012 |accessdate=10 December 2012}} In late October 2012, Talkalakh was under siege by the army.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} On 12 February 2013, a CNN report from inside Talkalakh revealed that the town itself was under rebel control, though government forces were only a matter of yards away, surrounding the town. Nevertheless, there was no fighting in or around the town thanks to a tenuous ceasefire between the warring sides brokered by a local sheikh and an Alawite member of parliament. Though isolated clashes have occurred, killing three rebels, and though government forces have been accused of harassing civilians since its implementation, the ceasefire has largely held. The town has returned to a degree of normal function, and some shops have started to re-open. Even the governor of Homs Province has been able to meet with rebels in the town, and has called the ceasefire an "experiment". Both sides reject sectarianism, stressing the need to keep foreign jihadist fighters out of the country. Nevertheless, rebels in the town stated that they remained committed to overthrowing Assad.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/02/11/world/meast/syria-civil-war/index.html?hpt=wo_c2|title=CNN exclusive: Fragile cease-fire holds in besieged town|last=Pleitgen|first=Frederik|first2=Jomana|last2=Karadsheh|publisher=CNN|accessdate=13 February 2013|location=Talkalakh|date=12 February 2013}} On 23 June, the Syrian Army captured the town. Following the assault, 39 local leaders of the Free Syrian Army surrendered and handed over their weapons. The Syrian opposition denied the town had fallen and claimed there was still fighting ongoing however reporters on the ground said there was no sign of it.{{cite news|title= Tal Kalakh: The Syrian town that lost the will to fight - The once rebel stronghold is back in the hands of the Syrian army |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/tal-kalakh-the-syrian-town-that-lost-the-will-to-fight-8673695.html|date=25 June 2013 | location=London|work=The Independent|first=Patrick|last=Cockburn}} |- |[[Abil]] |2,873 |[[Homs District]] |n[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Abil}}On 20 January 2013, it was reported that FSA overran the Um al-Sakhar air defense base, (that is located near the rebel held town of Abil and two km north of the village of [[al-Buwaydah al-Sharqiyah|al-Buwaydah]]) and took weapons and ammunition from it.{{cite news|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LwKRO0Ul-5k|title=ملخص أحداث اليوم مع أصيل العبداللة| date=20 January 2013|accessdate=20 January 2013|work= Syria Tomorrow}} On 18 April, the Syrian Army took control over the town of Abel{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/130418/syria-troops-seize-strategic-homs-village |title=Syria troops seize strategic Homs village |publisher=GlobalPost |date=18 April 2013 |accessdate=29 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131101234454/http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/130418/syria-troops-seize-strategic-homs-village |archivedate=1 November 2013 |df= }} |- |[[Al-Buwaydah al-Sharqiyah]] |3,196 |[[Al-Qusayr District]] |r[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Al-Buwaydah al-Sharqiyah}}The village was the site of the [[al-Buwaida al-Sharqiya massacre]] in May 2012, during the [[Syrian Civil War]]. Opposition activists claimed 13 factory workers were killed by the government's security forces, while Syrian government sources blamed rebel forces for the killings{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-18293155|title=New Syria 'mass killing' reported ahead of UN meeting|publisher=BBC News|date=1 June 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2153138/Syria-massacre-Factory-workers-ordered-bus-executed.html|title=Syrian factory workers ordered off bus and executed in third massacre in a week... as Hague refuses to rule out military action to oust Assad's brutal regime|date=1 June 2012|publisher=Daily Mail|location=London}} On 8 June 2013, the town was recaptured by the [[Syrian Army]] during the [[Al-Qusayr offensive]].{{cite news|title= Syrian Army Captures Village Near Qusair as Assad Extends Gains|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-06-08/syrian-army-captures-village-near-qusair-as-assad-extends-gains.html|author=Glen Carey|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=8 June 2013|accessdate=9 June 2013}} |- |[[Al-Husn, Syria|Al-Husn]] |8,980 |[[Talkalakh District]] |r[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Al-Husn}}On 22 January 2014, heavy clashes raged in al-Hosn{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/Jan-22/244899-syrian-shell-hits-home-in-n-lebanon-1-wounded.ashx#axzz2oNa3sbT8|title=Syrian shell hits home in n. Lebanon, 1 wounded|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=25 October 2014}} On 20 March 2014, the Syrian troops [[Battle of Hosn|recaptured the town]] of Al-Hosn close to the border.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jeQXsoz6rXkJ9LeHM356Xre4hAJA?docId=04b266b0-18a3-4c78-8bf1-ef29065767ee&hl=en|title=Cross-border fire by Syria army 'wounds 25' in northern Lebanon|publisher=|accessdate=26 May 2017}} |- |Outside listed towns in [[Homs Governorate|Homs G.]] | |— |r[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Others Homs}}Since June 2012, [[Free Syrian Army|FSA]] has control of parts of rural Homs. At the beginning of 2015 the Syrian troops controls most of Homs province.{{cite web|url=http://aranews.net/2015/03/70-pro-assad-forces-killed-in-central-syria-amid-isis-led-attacks/|title=Seventy pro-Assad forces killed in central Syria amid ISIS-led attacks|work=ARA News|accessdate=27 May 2015}} At May 2018, the Syrian Army and allies regain full control of the rebel-held northern Homs pocket, including [[al-Rastan|Rastan]], [[Talbiseh]], and [[Houla]]{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria/syrian-rebels-pull-out-of-their-last-besieged-area-idUSKCN1IH14K|title=Syrian rebels pull out of their last besieged area|work=[[Reuters]]|date=16 May 2018}} ''See also: [[Northern Homs offensive (April–May 2018)]].'' |} ==Idlib Governorate== {| class="toccolours sortable" border="1" cellpadding="3" style="border-collapse:collapse" |+ |- style="background:lavender;" !Name !Population ![[Districts of Syria|District]] !Held by !History during the [[Syrian Civil War]] |- |[[Idlib]] |98,791 |[[Idlib District]] |y[[File:Flag of Hayat Tahrir al-Sham.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Idlib}}Additional armored and artillery units arrived outside Idlib by 11 March and began deploying into the city by 12 March. On 12 February 2012, the entire city of Idlib was under opposition control, but was preparing for an attack by the government.{{cite web|last=Crawford |first=Alex |url=http://news.sky.com/home/world-news/article/16167393 |title=Opposition Stronghold Prepares For Assault |publisher=News.sky.com |date=12 February 2012 |accessdate=11 July 2012}} In mid-March 2012, rebels in Idlib offered stiff resistance but could not defeat the military’s tanks and the city fell in a matter of days.Holliday, Joseph (June 2012), [http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/Syrias_MaturingInsurgency_21June2012.pdf Syria’s Maturing Insurgency, 5.], Institute for the Study of War As of 7 June 2012, the edges of the city and the surrounding areas belong to the rebels.David Enders, [http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2012/06/07/151521/in-northern-syria-rebels-now-control.html "In northern Syria, rebels now control many towns and villages,"] McClatchy Newspapers, 7 June 2012. On 20 January 2013 a coordinated attack on Idlib city was begun by the FSA. They overran several checkpoints on the Western edges of Idlib, one attack at Rodoko checkpoint led to the killing of 15 Syrian Army soldiers (the rest fled on foot) and allowed rebels to capture 3 tanks and the checkpoints weapons cache.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/middle-east/syria/130120/syria-war-idlib |title=Syria: 'The War for Idlib' begins |publisher=GlobalPost |date=20 January 2013 |accessdate=29 August 2013}}

20% |{{anchor|Idlib-outside}}{{anchor|Others Idlib}}By June 2012, large parts of Idlib Governorate are controlled by [[Free Syrian Army|FSA]] who (along with local people), administered justice and the distribution of supplies to residents. [[Sham Falcons]] (led by General [[Mustafa al-Sheikh]]) operate in [[Zawiya Mountain|Jabal al-Zawiya]].{{cite web|url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=efe_1346187240 |title=FSA shells building full of regime forces with tank |publisher=Liveleak |date=28 August 2012 |accessdate=28 August 2012}} Eight out of the 35 villages of the Zawiya Mountain, around 25% percent, were reportedly under opposition control.{{cite web|url=http://www.islamweb.net/emainpage/index.php?page=articles&lang=A&id=178359 |title=On the front lines of Syria's guerrilla war |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=17 June 2012 |accessdate=11 July 2012}} On 18 October 2012, [[Al Jazeera]] reported that rebels were giving classes to children in caves in Jabal al-Zawiya after the regime destroyed schools{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M3nteE8YNc0 |title=مؤثر الكهوف في سوريا تتحول الى مدارس |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=18 October 2012 |accessdate=18 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150523000017/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M3nteE8YNc0 |archivedate=23 May 2015 }}
By November 2012, the FSA had taken control of 65% of the Governorate.Holliday, Joseph (9 November 2012), [http://www.understandingwar.org/map/campaign-northern-syria-november-2012 The Campaign in Northern Syria, November 2012], Institute for the Study of War
{{anchor|Zarzur}} According to [[Human Rights Watch]], when rebels took control of the northern village of [[Zarzur]] on 11 December 2012, they vandalised and deliberately set fire to a Shi'a ''[[hussainia]]''. According to residents, government forces had used the building as a barracks, but had abandoned it due to local complaints before the town was taken by rebels. The town's Shi'a minority has since largely fled the village.{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/01/23/syria-attacks-religious-sites-raise-tensions|title=Syria: Attacks on Religious Sites Raise Tensions|date=23 January 2013|publisher=Human Rights Watch|accessdate=30 January 2013}} Al Nusra Front and a number of Islamist militias, along with a small number of FSA groups, now controlled between 70 and 80 percent of Idlib province.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Dec-16/281204-wadi-deif-military-base-falls-to-syrian-jihadis-rebels.ashx|title=Wadi Deif military base falls to Syrian jihadis, rebels|publisher=The Daily Star|accessdate=16 December 2014}} ''See also: [[2011–2012 Idlib Governorate clashes]], [[Summer 2011 Jabal al-Zawiya operation]], [[October 2011 Jabal al-Zawiya clashes]], [[December 2011 Jabal al-Zawiya massacres]], [[December 2011 Syrian–Turkish border clash]], [[April 2012 Idlib Governorate Operation]] and [[Idlib Governorate clashes (2014)]].'' |} ==Latakia Governorate== {| class="toccolours sortable" border="1" cellpadding="3" style="border-collapse:collapse" |+ |- style="background:lavender;" !Name !Population ![[Districts of Syria|District]] !Held by !History during the [[Syrian Civil War]] |- |[[Latakia]] |383,786 |[[Latakia District]] |n[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Latakia}}''See [[Latakia#civilwar|Latakia (Syrian Civil War)]].'' |- |[[Al-Haffah]] |4,298 |[[Al-Haffah District]] |n[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Al-Haffah}}Al-Haffah is a [[Sunni]] Muslim town that lies in the foothills of the coastal mountains that form the heartland of [[Bashar al-Assad|Assad]]'s [[Alawi]] sect. It is strategically located close to the port city of [[Latakia]], as well as, the [[Turkey|Turkish]] border which has been used by the rebels to smuggle people and supplies.{{cite news|last=Solomon |first=Erika |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/12/us-syria-crisis-haffeh-idUSBRE85B0DT20120612 |title=Syrian rebels smuggle civilians from battered Haffeh |publisher=Reuters.com |date= 12 June 2012|accessdate=29 August 2013}} On 12 June 2012, the [[Battle of Al-Haffah|military recaptured al-Haffah]],{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-18421334 |title=Syrian government forces 'retake mountain town of Haffa' |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=13 June 2012 |accessdate=29 August 2013}} and the remaining 200 [[Free Syrian Army|FSA]] fighters under heavy bombardment by government forces withdrew from the town. FSA said that the fact that Al-Haffah is surrounded by Alawi villages did not help them.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/12/us-syria-crisis-haffeh-rebels-idUSBRE85B1CY20120612 |title=Syrian rebels withdraw from besieged Hafffeh: spokesman |publisher=Reuters.com |date= 12 June 2012|accessdate=29 August 2013}}[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jqLDPMMixj8 Syrian Young men take up arms in Syria's west], Al Jazeera, 29 August 2012 The rebels were reported to have retreated to Turkey.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} |- |[[Jableh]] |53,989 |[[Jableh District]] |n[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Jableh}}Since June 2012, the government has maintained control. |- |[[Qardaha]] |8,671 |[[Qardaha District]] |n[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Qardaha}}''See [[Qardaha#civilwar|Qardaha (Syrian Civil War)]].'' |- |[[Kesab]] |1,754 |[[Latakia District]] |y[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]] |{{anchor|Kesab}}Kesab, which has a border post, is 3 kilometers away from the [[Turkey|Turkish]] border and is mainly populated by [[Armenians in Syria|Armenians]]{{cite book |last=Mannheim |first=Ivan |title=Syria and Lebanon Handbook: The Travel Guide |year=2001 |publisher=Footprint Travel Guides |isbn=1-900949-90-3 |page=299}} with an [[Alawite]] minority. On 13 October 2012, rebels were attacking towards the town. Since November 2012, [[Syrian Turkmen|Turkmen]] rebels tried to take control of the town and its border post, however they were prevented from doing so by the local Alawite militias formed there.BBC News (4 December 2012), [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-19285076 Syria: Mapping the insurgency, December 2012], BBC News Local Alawite militias continue to exercise control over the area.Mohammad D. (5 September 2012), [http://www.joshualandis.com/blog/?p=15979&cp=all "The Formation of Alawite Militias in the Kassab region"], SyriaComment In late December, the town was reportedly shelled by unspecified forces, but no residents were killed or injured.{{cite news|url=http://armenpress.am/eng/news/704049/missiles-did-not-cause-casualties-in-armenian-populated-kessad.html|title=Missiles did not cause casualties in Armenian-populated Kessad [sic]|date=27 December 2012|publisher=Armenpress|accessdate=5 January 2013}} On 24 March 2014, the Islamist rebels and their jihadist ally Al-Nusra Front seized the small city of Kasab and nearby Kasab border crossing.{{cite web|url=http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/123639-rebels-seize-border-village-as-regime-warplanes-bomb-frontier|title=Rebels Seize Border Village as Regime Warplanes Bomb Frontier|work=Naharnet|accessdate=25 October 2014}} However they were repelled and forced back by the Syrian army and allied NDF forces (including by Syrian Resistance of Ali Kayali) by the end of [[2014 Latakia offensive|June 2014]]. |- |Outside listed towns in [[Latakia Governorate|Latakia G.]] | |— |p[[File:Flag of the United Arab Republic.svg|40px]]
97%[[File:Flag of Hayat Tahrir al-Sham.svg|40px]][[File:Syria-flag 1932-58 1961-63.svg|40px]]
3% |{{anchor|Others Latakia}}{{anchor|Ayn al-Ashara}}{{anchor|Ubin}}{{anchor|Ghassaniyeh}}{{anchor|Jdeideh}}[[File:2015 Latakia Frontlines.svg|250px|thumb|right|Situation in the Latakia Governorate in December 2016{{leftlegend|#EDC4BE|Syrian Army control}}{{leftlegend|#CDEBC9|Opposition control}}]]Since June 2012, [[Free Syrian Army|FSA]] controls a small part in the north east. In late July 2012, [[France 24]] reported that the army has been burning forests to avoid FSA hiding in them. By October 2012, the FSA slowly captured most of the [[Jabal al-Akrad|Jebel Akrad]] and [[Jebel Turkman]] mountain ranges in the north. Rebels have taken control of six [[Alawi]]te villages in the region, in some cases intimidating the locals to leave by way of kidnappings, theft, and looting of homes. There are fears even among elements of the opposition that if the conflict continues to spread, rebel forces may perpetrate larger sectarian revenge killings.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/9751531/Syrian-rebels-cut-off-Bashar-al-Assads-escape-route.html|title=Syrian rebels cut off Bashar al-Assad's escape route |last=Sherlock |first=Ruth |date=17 December 2012|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=7 January 2013 |location=London}} The region of the province now controlled by rebels was home to a sizeable Kurdish minority prior to the war. Most [[Kurd]]s have fled from the 60 villages in the region they once inhabited due to the fighting, but many are too poor to afford to flee to neighbouring [[Turkey]]. Those who are internally displaced have resettled in refugee camps close to the border, such as one near [[#Khirbet Aljoz|Khirbet al-Joz]], where a farmer has been converting part of his land with the help of a [[Qatar]]i company into a camp that will able to house 10,000 refugees once completed.{{cite news|url=https://now.mmedia.me/lb/en/nowsyrialatestnews/syria_war_leaves_ghost_towns_in_kurdish_region |title=Syria war leaves ghost towns in Kurdish region |last=AFP |date=27 January 2013|publisher=NOW|accessdate=27 January 2013}} According to Human Rights Watch, rebel forces also broke into and looted churches in the Christian villages of Ghassaniyeh and Jdeideh after taking control of them, though it was not clear if sectarianism was the motive. Several locals had been kidnapped by rebels, who also looted homes. Much of the population of the villages had fled. {{short description|ballroom dancing as a sport}} {{Infobox sport | name = Dancesport | image = MIT 2006 Standard Prechamp Final 2.jpg | imagesize = 220px | caption = An amateur dancesport competition at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] | union = [[World DanceSport Federation|WDSF]] and [[World Dance Council|WDC]] | nickname = | first = | firstlabel = | country/region = | registered = | clubs = | contact = | team = | mgender = Yes | category = | equipment = | venue = [[Ballroom]] | obsolete = | olympic = No | paralympic = | IWGA = [[1997 World Games|1997]]{{snds}}present }}
'''Dancesport''' denotes competitive [[ballroom dance|ballroom dancing]],<ref name=DancesportIreland>{{cite web|title=''History of Dancesport by Dancesport Ireland'' |url=http://www.dancesportireland.org/about_dancesport.html |accessdate=2009-03-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106130437/http://www.dancesportireland.org/about_dancesport.html |archivedate=January 6, 2009 }}</ref> as contrasted to social or exhibition dancing. In the case of [[Wheelchair DanceSport|wheelchair dancesport]], at least one of the dancers is in a [[wheelchair]].
Dancesport events are sanctioned and regulated by dancesport organizations at the national and international level, such as the [[World DanceSport Federation]].
The name was invented to help competitive ballroom dancing gain Olympic recognition.<ref>McMain, Julie 2006. ''Glamour addiction: inside the American ballroom dance industry''. Weslyan, Middletown CT. p1</ref> The physical demand of dancesport has been the subject of scientific research.<ref>Biomechanics of dancesport: a kinematic approach ISSN 0025-7826</ref><ref>Blanksby & Reidy 1988</ref><ref>[http://dance104.valuehost.co.uk/e107/page.php?12 Dancing as a Sport Article] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110202210308/http://dance104.valuehost.co.uk/e107/page.php?12 |date=2011-02-02 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.idsf.net/documents/dancesport_a_sport.pdf IDSF Research Paper] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090305105241/http://www.idsf.net/documents/dancesport_a_sport.pdf |date=2009-03-05 }}</ref>
==History== The first unofficial world championship took place in 1909,<ref name="ReferenceA"/> and the first formation team<ref>pattern or shadow dancing to a rehearsed routine by groups of couples</ref> was presented in 1932 by Olive Ripman at the Astoria Ballroom, London.<ref name=DancesportIreland /><ref>Spencer, Frank and Peggy 1968. ''Come dancing''. Allen, London. Chapter 3, p33.</ref> Dancesport was first broadcast on TV in 1960.<ref name="wdsf-history">{{cite web | title = ''WDSF History'' | url = http://www.worlddancesport.org/WDSF/History | accessdate = 2011-08-25}}</ref>
==Styles== The term ''dancesport'' applies to the [[Glossary of partner dance terms#International Style|International Style]],<ref name="newsab">{{cite news |work=Austin American-Statesman |title=Sweeping a dance floor near you |date=2000-09-22 |first=Sondra |last=Lomax |page=F1}}</ref> as well as [[Glossary of partner dance terms#American Style|American Style]] of competitive ballroom. It includes the following categories: * International Standard * International Latin * American Smooth * American Rhythm
These categories apply to both individual couples and [[formation dance]].
== International governing organizations ==
=== World Dance Council === {{Main|World Dance Council}}
The World Dance Council (WDC) is a registered limited company, and the legal successor to the [[International Council of Ballroom Dancing]] (ICBD), which was formed in 1950 in Edinburgh.<ref name="ReferenceA">[[Lyndon Wainwright|Wainwright, Lyndon]] [1997]. ''The story of British popular dance''. International Dance Publications, Brighton.</ref> The WDC operates through a general council and two committees: * The World Dance Sport Committee regulates professional dancesport at the international level. * The World Social Dance Committee "deals with all matters of the dance profession that relate to the activities of Dance Schools and Dance Teachers".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dancewdc.org/index.php?set_ActivMenu=95 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725220028/http://www.dancewdc.org/index.php?set_ActivMenu=95 |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }}</ref> It does not regulate social dance directly – that is the business of individual organisers, the dance teacher organisations, such as the [[Imperial Society of Teachers of Dancing]], and the chains of dance teaching schools in the United States.
In 2007 the WDC Amateur League was created.<ref>{{cite web |title=To All Competitors, Coaches/Trainers |publisher=World Dance Council - Amateur League |url=http://www.wdcamateurleague.com/news_detail.php?news_id=68 |accessdate=2010-09-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101219033602/http://www.wdcamateurleague.com/news_detail.php?news_id=68 |archivedate=2010-12-19 |df= }}</ref> This organisation runs a number of competitions and has its own world ranking system for amateur dancers.
Each member country in the WDC has its own national organisation, such as the [[British Dance Council]], which acts as a forum for the many interested parties in that country. The national bodies decide on their delegates to the WDC.
=== World DanceSport Federation === {{Main|World DanceSport Federation}}
The '''World DanceSport Federation''' (WDSF), formerly the International DanceSport Federation (IDSF), is the international [[Sport governing body|governing body]] of dancesport, as recognised by the ''[[International Olympic Committee]]'' (IOC).
Founded in 1957 as the ''International Council of Amateur Dancers'' (ICAD), it took up the name IDSF in 1990. In 2011 it was renamed to WDSF to emphasise the global character of the organization.
In the past, the focus of the IDSF was on administering amateur dancers and competitions. However, in 2010 the IDSF Professional Division was created (formerly known as the IPDSC), which extended this focus to professional dancesport.<ref name="wdsf-history"/>
WDSF members are not permitted to dance in competitions unless they are granted by the WDSF, or one of its member federations.<ref>{{cite web | title = ''Code of Conduct and Standards of Ethics'' | url = http://www.worlddancesport.org/Rule/Athlete/Operating%20Policies | accessdate = 2011-08-25}}</ref> *This policy was revoked in 2012 at the Annual General Meeting by vote of the members. The WDSF now supports an athlete's "right to dance".
== Competitions == [[File:Ballroom dance competition cha cha 3.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Junior [[Cha-cha-cha (dance)|cha-cha-cha]] competition in [[Czech Republic]]]]
There are a wide variety of dance competitions. They range from the well known [[Blackpool Dance Festival]], an event open to all, to competitions conducted exclusively for university students, such as those hosted by the [[Inter Varsity Dance Association]] in the UK.
Amateur competitions commonly include events that group dancers by age, experience, or both. For example, events might group young dancers by age, such as: juvenile (<12yrs), junior (12-16yrs), and youth (16-19yrs). Events may sometimes cover a wide range of ages, with groupings such as: under 21yrs, adult, senior I (Over 35yrs), senior II (Over 45yrs), senior III (Over 55yrs, and senior IV (Over 65yrs).
Competitors may also be grouped by experience level, with categories such as Beginner, Novice, Intermediate, Pre-Amateur and Amateur. These generally correspond to the number of the dances to be performed in the competition, with Beginners performing one dance, and those at Amateur level performing five. In some competitions these are categorized into grades from A to E, with "A" the equivalent of the Amateur level, and "E" corresponding to the "Beginner" level.
=== WDSF minimum competition dance area size standard === WDSF governing bodies in different countries have the flexibility to decide on the dance area size for competitions held in the country.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Location !! Official Standard !! Compare Square Meter !! Compare Square Feet |- | Europe || 26m x 16m || 416 || 4478 |- | China || 23m x 15m || 345 || 3714 |- | USA || 60' x 36' || 201 || 2160 |- | Canada || 60' x 35' || 195 || 2100 |}
In December 2011, the WDSF Open and the Australian Nationals were held at the Hisense Arena located within the Olympic park in Melbourne. The floor was at 84 by 37.7 meters which was 7.61 times the size of what WDSF requires.
=== Rules === The [[World Dance Council]] (WDC) rules for international competitions are lengthy and detailed.<ref>[http://www.dancewdc.org/download/7eTsDviYCPXgCx6LN7itu9WLM/WDC%20Competition%20Rules%20current%20-%20June%202009.pdf World Dance Council]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The music for competitions is kept confidential until the event. The music always follows a strict tempo and, for a couples competition, it will have a duration of no less than 90 seconds, and no more than two minutes.
Some elementary competitions are restricted to "basic" steps, but international competitions are open as to [[choreography]], within the limits of the traditional style of the individual dances. Only the [[Viennese waltz]] has defined choreography: it is limited to seven well-specified figures. Lifts are not permitted, except for Show Dance titles. The tempo for each dance is defined. In the finals, couples are marked under the [[skating system]] and judged by timing, footwork, rise and fall, alignment, direction and floor craft. Competitors must meet [[World Anti-Doping Agency]] rules.
===Dancesport as an Olympic event=== After a long campaign, the [[World DanceSport Federation]] (WDSF), formerly IDSF, was recognized by the [[International Olympic Committee]] as the sole representative body for dancesport, on September 5, 1997.<ref>Long, Daniel 1999. ''Qualifying for Olympic status: the process and implications for competitive ballroom dance''. Master's thesis, Brigham Young University.</ref><ref>[http://www.idsf.net/ ISDF]</ref> At that point, many dance organisations changed their titles to incorporate the word ''sport''. This recognition gives the IDSF, potentially, a unique status. The WDSF website shows letters and certificates from the IOC that recognise dancesport as an eligible sport for inclusion pursuant to rule 29 of the Olympic Charter.<ref name="ioc-letter">{{cite web |title=''Official Letter from Mr. Juan Antonio Samaranch'' |url=http://www.idsf.net/index.tpl?id=29 |accessdate=2010-09-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101013040944/http://www.idsf.net/index.tpl?id=29 |archivedate=2010-10-13 |df= }}</ref> <ref name="ioc-certificate">{{cite web | title = ''Official IOC Certificate'' | url = http://www.idsf.net/index.tpl?id=30 | accessdate = 2010-09-04 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100626010044/http://www.idsf.net/index.tpl?id=30 | archivedate = 2010-06-26 | df = }}</ref>
On its website, the IDSF gives an upbeat appraisal of the chances of dancesport being included in a future summer Olympic Games.<ref>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041017132959/http://www.idsf.net/press02/idsf0213.pdf |url=http://www.idsf.net/press02/idsf0213.pdf |title=IOC: Green Light for DanceSport|publisher=International DanceSport Federation|archivedate=2004-10-17}}</ref> However, dancesport has not been included as an official event at the Olympics since its recognition,<ref>{{cite web |work=Olympic.org - Official website of the Olympic Movement |url=http://www.olympic.org/uk/organisation/if/fi_uk.asp?id_federation=43 |title=International DanceSport Federation}}</ref> and there are many who doubt that it ever will.<ref>McMain, Julie 2006. ''Glamour addiction: inside the American ballroom dance industry''. Weslyan, Middletown CT. p101 note 2.</ref><ref>Hanley, Elizabeth A. 2000. A perennial dilemma: artistic sports in the Olympic Games. ''Journal of Olympic History'' p39–46.</ref> The 2008 [[2008 Summer Olympics|Beijing Olympics]] did not include ballroom dancing and neither did the 2012 [[London Olympics]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Olympic Sports London 2012 | publisher = Official site of the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games | url = http://www.london2012.com/games/olympic-sports/index.php | accessdate = 2010-09-09 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101125100752/http://www.london2012.com/games/olympic-sports/index.php | archivedate = 2010-11-25 | df = }}</ref> However, it was announced in December 2016 that the dancesport discipline of [[breakdancing]] would form part of the programme for the [[2018 Summer Youth Olympics]], with men's, women's and mixed-team events included in a one-on-one battle format.<ref>{{cite web|work=Olympic.org - Official website of the Olympic Movement|url=https://www.olympic.org/news/three-new-sports-to-join-buenos-aires-2018-yog-programme|title=Three new sports to join Buenos Aires 2018 YOG programme|accessdate=2017-08-25}}</ref>
===Physical demands===
Ballroom dancing is a partnered activity with a male and female counterpart. Over the years, competitive ballroom dancing has evolved so much in its choreography, requiring a higher level of athleticism. Many individuals that spectate or dance socially often underestimate the physical attributes and demands of ballroom dancing. In order to compete at a world level, elite competitive dancers undergo rigorous training to help and enhance their competition performance. These dancers seem to perform at such a high level of [[energy expenditure]] that a deeper understanding of these energy demands may help build specific training programs used to sustain a high quality dance performance consistent over a few rounds of a competition.
In 1988, an Australian study was conducted to determine the [[heart rate]] and estimated energy expended during ballroom dancing.<ref name="Blanksby, B. A. and Reidy, P. W. June 22, 1988">{{cite journal|last=Blanksby|first=B. A.|author2=Reidy, P. W.|title=Heart rate and estimated energy expenditure during ballroom dancing|journal=[[British Journal of Sports Medicine]]|date=June 1988|volume=22|issue=2|pages=57–60|pmid=3167503|pmc=1478556}}</ref> Professors Blanksby and Reidy of the Department of Human Movement and Recreation Studies at the University of Western had ten competitive ballroom dance couples simulate a dancesport competition, dancing their competitive routines in either the Latin American or Standard division.<ref name="Blanksby, B. A. and Reidy, P. W. June 22, 1988"/> After administrating all required laboratory tests (in order to record their height, weight, body fat percentage, fat free mass and the resting/maximal heart rate and [[VO2 max|VO2]] values), the couples danced a five-dance final, given a 15 to 20 second break between each dance.<ref name="Blanksby, B. A. and Reidy, P. W. June 22, 1988"/> Throughout the final their heart rates were telemetered and recorded. The purpose of this study was to estimate the energy requirements from heart rates acquired during competition simulation and previously recorded measures of VO2 and HR.
The average heart rate for male dancers in Standard was 170 beats min<sup>−1</sup> and 168 beats min<sup>−1</sup> in the Latin American.<ref name="Blanksby, B. A. and Reidy, P. W. June 22, 1988"/> Females elicited 179 beats min<sup>−1</sup> and 177 beats min<sup>−1</sup> respectively.<ref name="Blanksby, B. A. and Reidy, P. W. June 22, 1988"/> Astrand and Rodahl (1977) classify any exercise being extremely heavy if it results in a heart rate above 150 beats min<sup>−1</sup>.<ref>{{cite web|title=Textbook of Work Physiology. McGraw-HilBookCo.|author=Astrand, P.-O. and Rodahl, K. (1977)|accessdate=2 April 2013}}</ref> They also classify an exercise as extremely heavy if [[oxygen consumption]] is higher than 2.0L min<sup>−1</sup>.<ref>{{cite web|title=Textbook of Work Physiology. McGraw-HilBookCo.|author=Astrand, P.-O. and Rodahl, K. (1977)| accessdate= 2 April 2013}}</ref> All but the females in the Standard dance sequence didn’t exceed an oxygen consumption level of 2.0L min<sup>−1</sup>.<ref name="Blanksby, B. A. and Reidy, P. W. June 22, 1988"/> Finally, the energy expenditure for male athletes was estimated to be 54.1 ± 8.1 kJ min<sup>−1</sup> for Standard and 54.0± 9.6kJ min<sup>−1</sup> in the Latin American dances.<ref name="Blanksby, B. A. and Reidy, P. W. June 22, 1988"/> For females it was 34.7 ± 3.8 kJ min<sup>−1</sup> and 36.1 ± 4.1 kJ min<sup>−1</sup> respectively.<ref name="Blanksby, B. A. and Reidy, P. W. June 22, 1988"/>
Two other similar experiments were conducted exhibiting very similar results and analyses.<ref name="Massidda, M. M., Cugusi L. C., Ibba M. I., Tradori l. t., Calò C, M,, December 11, 2011 206&rft_id=info:pmid/22211197&rft.externalDocID=22211197">{{cite journal|last=Massidda|first=M.|author2=Cugusi, L |author3=Ibba, M |author4=Tradori, I |author5= Calò, C.M. |title=Energy expenditure during competitive Latin American dancing simulation|journal=Medical problems of performing artists|date=Dec 2011|volume=26|issue=4|pages=206–10|pmid=22211197}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Heart Rate and Blood Lactate Concentration during Ballroom Dancing|url=http://bf4dv7zn3u.search.serialssolutions.com/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&ctx_enc=info%3Aofi%2Fenc%3AUTF-8&rfr_id=info:sid/summon.serialssolutions.com&rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&rft.genre=article&rft.atitle=Heart+Rate+and+Blood+Lactate+Concentration+during+Ballroom+Dancing&rft.jtitle=Medicine+%26+Science+in+Sports+%26+Exercise&rft.au=Jensen%2C+Kurt&rft.au=J%3F%3Frgensen%2C+Susanne&rft.au=Johansen%2C+Lars&rft.date=2002-05-01&rft.issn=0195-9131&rft.eissn=1530-0315&rft.volume=34&rft.issue=5&rft.spage=34&rft_id=info:doi/10.1097%2F00005768-200205001-01732&rft.externalDBID=n%2Fa&rft.externalDocID=10_1097_00005768_200205001_01732|author=Jensen, K.J., Jørgensen, S. J., Johansen, L.J. (2001)| accessdate=26 March 2013}}</ref> In all three of the experiments, significant differences in the energy expenditure between the male and female athletes were noticed. Generally males had a higher energy expenditure than their female counterparts. This is evident due to the anthropometric differences between the two sexes and the oxygen transport capacity.<ref name="Massidda, M. M., Cugusi L. C., Ibba M. I., Tradori l. t., Calò C, M,, December 11, 2011 206&rft_id=info:pmid/22211197&rft.externalDocID=22211197"/>
Comparing the mean gross energy expenditures (in kJ min<sup>−1</sup>) between ballroom dancing and other sports, it is evident that competitive dancing is equally as demanding in comparison to other sporting activities such as basketball (35.83 kJ min<sup>−1</sup>) or cross-country running (44.37kJ min<sup>−1</sup>) (Consolazioetal,1963),<ref>{{cite web|title= Physiological Measurement of Metabolic Functions in Man. McGraw-Hill BookCo.|author=Consolazio, C.,Johnson, R. and Pecora, L., (1963)|accessdate=2 April 2013}}</ref> and that ballroom dancing requires a [[cardiovascular system]] to be able to work at a high energy level in order to match the given physiological strain.

A '''data jam''' is a technically oriented workshop exercise where people solve problems using data sets. The events can produce visual data, analytics and applications.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://codeforjc.org/PATHDataJam/|title=Path Data Jam|work=Code for JC|publisher=St Peters University|accessdate=8 April 2015}}</ref>
Examples include the Hudson Data Jam, hosted by Cary Institute of Environmental Systems, in which students are asked to tell a story based on raw data collected from the watershed of the [[Hudson River]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caryinstitute.org/students/hudson-data-jam-competition/data-jam-data-sets|title=2015 Hudson Data Jam Competition|publisher=Cary Institute|accessdate=8 April 2015}}</ref> and the Capitol Code, a data jam based on the Office of the Minnesota Secretary of State.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://capitolcode.mn.gov/2014/01/announcing-capitol-code-an-open-data-jam/|title=Capitol Code : An Open Data Jam|publisher=Office of the Minnesota Secretary of State|accessdate=8 April 2015}}</ref>

{{About|a 1904 attack on British fishermen|the naval battles|Battle of Dogger Bank (disambiguation)}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{coord|54.724|2.769|display=title|region:GB_scale:5000000}} [[File:Doggerbank.jpg|thumb|right|Location of the [[Dogger Bank]] in the [[North Sea]].]]
The '''Dogger Bank incident''' (also known as the '''North Sea Incident''', the '''Russian Outrage''' or the '''Incident of Hull''') occurred on the night of 21/22 October 1904, when the [[Baltic Fleet]] of [[Imperial Russian Navy]] mistook a British [[Commercial trawler|trawler]] fleet from [[Kingston upon Hull]] in the [[Dogger Bank]] area of the [[North Sea]] for an [[Imperial Japanese Navy]] force and fired on them. Russian warships also fired on each other in the chaos of the melée.<ref>{{harvnb|Wood|1911|p=275-286}}</ref> Three British fishermen died and a number were wounded. One sailor and a priest aboard a Russian cruiser caught in the crossfire were also killed. The incident almost led to war between Britain and Russia.<ref name="WAROFRISINGSUN">{{harvnb|Connaughton|1988|p=247, 250 & 259}}</ref>
==Incident==
The [[Battle of Tsushima#The Second Pacific Squadron|Russian warships]] involved in the incident were en route to the Far East, to reinforce the 1st Pacific Squadron stationed at [[Port Arthur naval base|Port Arthur]], and later [[Vladivostok]], during the [[Russo-Japanese War]]. Because of the fleet's alleged sightings of balloons and four enemy cruisers the day previously, coupled with "the possibility that the Japanese might surreptitiously have sent ships around the world to attack"<ref name="Busch p. 90, 91">{{harvnb|Busch|1969|p=90, 91}}</ref> them, the Russian admiral, [[Zinovy Rozhestvensky]], called for increased vigilance, issuing an order that "no vessel of any sort must be allowed to get in among the fleet".<ref name="Busch p. 90, 91"/> [[File:Aurora 1903.jpg|thumb|The ''[[Aurora (cruiser)|Aurora]]'', a Russian cruiser attacked by other Russian ships during the incident.]] [[File:Dogger Bank Russian Outrage incident 1904 St Andrews Dock, Hull postcard.jpg|thumb|Damaged trawlers after return to St Andrews Dock, Hull]] It was known that enemy intelligence had been heavily active in the region.<ref>{{harvnb|Busch|1969|p=121}}</ref> Torpedo boats, a recent development of the major navies, had the potential to damage and sink large warships, and were very difficult to detect, causing psychological stress on sailors at war.
Similar accidents and rumours affected the Russian fleet: there was a general fear of attack, with widespread rumours that a fleet of Japanese torpedo boats were stationed off the Danish coast, talk of the Japanese having mined the seas, and alleged sightings of Japanese submarines. Before the Dogger Bank incident, the nervous Russian fleet fired on fishermen carrying consular dispatches from Russia to them, near the Danish coast, without causing any damage due to their poor gunnery.<ref name="HULL" />
After navigating a non-existent minefield, the Russian fleet sailed into the North Sea. The disaster of 21 October began in the evening, when the captain of the supply ship ''Kamchatka'' (Камчатка), which was last in the Russian line, took a passing [[Sweden|Swedish]] ship for a Japanese torpedo boat and radioed that he was being attacked. Later that night, during fog, the officers on duty sighted the British trawlers, interpreted their signals incorrectly and classified them as Japanese torpedo boats, despite being more than {{convert|20,000|mi|km||sigfig=1}} from Japan. The Russian warships illuminated the trawlers with their searchlights and opened fire. The British trawler ''Crane'' was sunk, and its captain and first mate were killed. Four other trawlers were damaged, and six other fishermen were wounded, one of whom died a few months later. As the trawlers had their nets down, they were unable to flee and, in the general chaos, Russian ships shot at each other: the cruisers [[Russian cruiser Aurora|''Aurora'']] and [[Russian armoured cruiser Dmitrii Donskoi|''Dmitrii Donskoi'']] were taken for Japanese warships and bombarded by seven battleships sailing in formation, damaging both ships and killing a chaplain and at least one sailor and severely wounding another. During the pandemonium, several Russian ships signalled torpedoes had hit them, and on board the battleship [[Russian battleship Borodino|''Borodino'']] rumours spread that the ship was being boarded by the Japanese, with some crews donning life vests and lying prone on the deck, and others drawing cutlasses. More serious losses to both sides were only avoided by the extremely low quality of Russian gunnery, with the battleship [[Russian battleship Oryol|''Oryol'']] reportedly firing more than 500 shells without hitting anything.<ref name="HULL" /> After twenty minutes' firing the fishermen saw a blue light signal on one of the warships, the order to cease firing.<ref>[http://www.scarboroughsmaritimeheritage.org.uk/adoggerbank.php The dogger bank incident in 1904 – The Russian fleet attacks Hull trawlers] – [[Scarborough Maritime Heritage Centre]]</ref>
== Aftermath == The incident led to a serious diplomatic conflict between Russia and Britain, which was particularly dangerous due to the [[Anglo-Japanese Alliance]]. In the aftermath some British newspapers called the Russian fleet '[[pirates]]' and Admiral Rozhestvensky was heavily criticised for not leaving the British sailors lifeboats. The editorial of the morning's ''[[The Times|Times]]'' was particularly scathing: :''"It is almost inconceivable that any men calling themselves seamen, however frightened they might be, could spend twenty minutes bombarding a fleet of fishing boats without discovering the nature of their target."<ref name="WAROFRISINGSUN"/>'' [[File:Dogger Bank Proceedings.png|thumb|left|Session of the International Commission of Inquiry]] [[File:Dogger Bank fishermen.png|thumb|left|British fishermen in Paris to testify before the Commission]] The [[Royal Navy]] prepared for war, with 28 battleships of the [[Home Fleet]] being ordered to raise steam and prepare for action, while British cruiser squadrons shadowed the Russian fleet as it made its way through the [[Bay of Biscay]] and down the coast of [[Portugal]]. Under diplomatic pressure, the Russian government agreed to investigate the incident, and Rozhestvensky was ordered to dock in [[Vigo]], Spain, where he left behind those officers considered responsible (as well as at least one officer who had been critical of him).<ref name="HULL">[http://www.hullwebs.co.uk/content/l-20c/disaster/dogger-bank/voyage-of-dammed.htm Dogger Bank – Voyage of the Damned] ('Hullwebs – History of Hull' website. Retrieved 8 September 2007.)</ref> From Vigo, the main Russian fleet then approached [[Tangiers]], [[Morocco]], and lost contact with the ''Kamchatka'' for several days. The ''Kamchatka'' eventually rejoined the fleet and claimed that she had engaged three Japanese warships and fired over 300 shells: the ships she had actually fired at were a Swedish merchantman, a German trawler, and a French schooner. As the fleet left Tangiers, one ship accidentally severed the city's underwater telegraph cable with her anchor, preventing communications with Europe for four days.<ref name="HULL"/>
Due to concerns that the draught of the newer battleships (which had proven to be considerably greater than designed)<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/officialhistoryn03grea|title=Official history, naval and military, of the Russo-Japanese War. Prepared by the Historical section of the Committee of Imperial Defence|last=Great Britain Committee of Imperial Defence|first=|publisher=His Majesty's Stationery Office|year=1920|isbn=|volume=III|location=|publication-place=London|pages=27-31}}</ref> would prevent their passage through the Suez Canal, the fleet separated after leaving Tangiers on November 3, 1904. The newer battleships and a few cruisers proceeded around the Cape of Good Hope under command of Admiral Rozhestvensky while the older battleships and lighter cruisers made their way through the Suez Canal under the command of Admiral von Felkerzam. They planned to rendezvous in Madagascar and both sections of the fleet successfully completed this part of the journey<ref name=":0" />. The fleet then proceeded to the [[Sea of Japan]] where it was soundly defeated in the [[Battle of Tsushima]].
On 25 November 1904, the British and the Russian governments signed a joint agreement in which they agreed to submit the issue to an international commission of inquiry whose proceedings were to be based on the Hague Convention.<ref>[http://www.worldcourts.com/ici/eng/decisions/1904.11.25_doggerbank/index.htm Joint British-Russian declaration] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081013053249/http://www.worldcourts.com/ici/eng/decisions/1904.11.25_doggerbank/index.htm |date=13 October 2008 }}</ref> The International Commission met in Paris from 9 January to 25 February 1905.<ref>{{harvnb|Jackson|1974|p=65–66}}</ref> The report produced by the International Commission concluded that: "the commissioners declare that their findings, which are therein formulated, are not, in their opinion, of a nature to cast any discredit upon the military qualities or the humanity of Admiral Rojdestvensky, or of the personnel of his squadron". It also concluded as follows: "the commissioners take pleasure in recognising, unanimously, that Admiral Rozhestvensky personally did everything he could, from beginning to end of the incident, to prevent trawlers, recognised as such, from being fired upon by the squadron".<ref>[http://www.worldcourts.com/ici/eng/decisions/1905.02.26_doggerbank.htm Dogger Bank Incident Final Report]</ref> [[File:North Sea Incident 1904 - Memorial - geograph.org.uk - 264822.jpg|thumb|Fisherman's Memorial]] Russia voluntarily paid a compensation of £66,000 to the fishermen.<ref>{{harvnb|Merills|1999}}</ref> In 1906 the Fisherman's Memorial was unveiled in [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]] to commemorate the deaths of the three British sailors. The approx. 18 feet high statue shows the dead fisherman George Henry Smith and carries the following inscription:
:''Erected by public subscription to the memory of George Henry Smith (skipper) and William Richard Legget (third hand), of the steam-trawler CRANE, who lost their lives through the action of the Russian Baltic Fleet in the North Sea, 22 October 1904, and Walter Whelpton, skipper of the trawler MINO, who died through shock, May 1905.''

'''Europe-Iran Forum''' is a series of events originally hosted by the Development Institute [[Paris]], [[BHB Emissary]] and [[European Voice]] magazine in 2014. The event's main goal is to act as a non-partisan meeting ground for European and Iranian businesses to discuss future cooperation post [[sanctions against Iran|sanctions]].<ref>http://www.europeiranforum2.com/</ref>
Following the historic [[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action|Joint Action Plan]] agreement reached by [[Iran]] and the Group [[P5+1]] in November 2013, a series of economic sanctions were lifted, rekindling commercial interest in Iran throughout Europe.<ref name=9191**1424>{{cite news|url=http://www.irna.ir/en/News/2771192/|accessdate=17 April 2015|agency=IRNA}}</ref>
The event, a first of its kind to offer Iran as a potential investment destination garnered attention in the press including the [[BBC]]. The Europe-Iran forum is the first event created by the private sector to have the moral support from the government of President [[Hassan Rouhani]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=BBC|title=Iran Forum Raises Eyebrows|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-29646763}}</ref>
Scheduled speakers included Martin Sorrell, chief executive of advertising group WPP, as well as [[Jack Straw]] and Hubert Vedrine, former British and French foreign ministers respectively. The Forum also has the blessing of Rouhani, whose chief of staff has written a letter of support to the organizers, media company European Voice.
The first post-sanctions conference was held in [[Vienna]], Austria and second event has been slated for fall 2015 in the Swiss city of [[Geneva]].<ref>{{cite web|title=EU Iran Forum 2|url=http://www.europeiranforum2.com/location/|website=EU Iran Forum 2}}</ref> The event's stated goal is to provide a platform for both Iranian and [[international banking]] and finance groups to discuss future cooperation post-sanctions.
The second forum was dubbed the Europe-Iran Forum, considering it was being held in the [[Swiss]] city of [[Geneva]], and not in a [[European Union]] country.
==Notable speakers==
*'''[[Jack Straw]], former [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] British Foreign Secretary *'''[[Sir Martin Sorrell]], CEO of advertising agency [[WPP plc]] *'''[[Rouzbeh Pirouz]], founder of the [[Iranian Business School]] and [[Turquoise Partners]] *'''[[Neda Amidi]], associate of the [[Plug & Play Tech Center]] in California *'''[[Parviz Aghili]], CEO of [[Middle East Bank]] *'''[[Dominique de Villepin]], former French foreign minister
==Criticism==
The event has come under heavy pressure from supporters of [[Israel]] for its pro-Iran stance. Israeli newspapers in 2014 slammed the event calling it a "travesty of the gravest proportions".<ref>{{cite news|title=Times of Israel|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/israel-fumes-at-post-sanctions-iran-conference-in-london/|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref>
The [[Gatestone Interview]] reviewed the first event stating "The Europe-Iran Forum marks Iran's preparations for a nuclear-capable Iran in a comfortable post-sanctions world, for which the regime is advocating in spite of its continued sponsorship of terror abroad and the oppression of its citizens at home."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Westrop|first1=Samuel|title=UK: Iran Lobbies against Sanctions|url=http://www.gatestoneinstitute.org/4802/europe-iran-forum|website=Gatestone Institute|accessdate=17 April 2015}}</ref>
