{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = New York Fashion Week | logo = | image = Diane von Fürstenberg Spring-Summer 2014 06.jpg | imagesize = | caption = [[Liu Wen]], [[supermodel]], walks the runway modeling fashions by designer [[Diane von Fürstenberg]] at New York Fashion Week 2013. | genre = Clothing and fashion exhibitions | date = | frequency = Semi-annually | location = [[Manhattan]] (primarily at Skylight Clarkson Square and Industria ) | country = [[United States]] | first = 1943 | founder_name = [[Eleanor Lambert]] | prev = <!-- [[previous event]] --> | next = <!-- [[next event]] --> | participants = | attendance = | area = | budget = | people = | member = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''New York Fashion Week''', held in February and September of each year, is a semi-annual series of events (generally lasting 7–9 days) when international [[Fashion design|fashion collections]] are shown to buyers, the press, and the general public. It is one of four major [[fashion week]]s in the world, collectively known as the "Big 4," along with those in [[Paris Fashion Week|Paris]], [[London Fashion Week|London]] and [[Milan Fashion Week|Milan]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Bradford |first1=Julie |title=Fashion Journalism |publisher=Routledge |year=2014 |page=129 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H2xeBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA129}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Susan |last=Dillon |title=The Fundamentals of Fashion Management |publisher=A&C Black |year=2011 |page=115 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3XFMAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA115}}</ref> The [[Council of Fashion Designers of America]] (CFDA) created the modern notion of a centralized “New York Fashion Week” in 1993, although cities like London were already using their city’s name in conjunction with the words “fashion week” in the 1980s. NYFW is based on a much older series of events called “Press Week,” founded in 1943.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newyorkfashionweeklive.com/history-of-new-york-fashion-week |title=History of New York Fashion Week – New York Fashion Week |publisher=}}</ref>
It has consisted of numerous branded events, such as Olympus Fashion Week New York<ref name="olympusamerica.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.olympusamerica.com/cpg_section/cpg_pressDetails.asp?pressNo=286 |title=OLYMPUS NAMED TITLE SPONSOR OF NEW YORK FASHION WEEK |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161025095552/http://www.olympusamerica.com/cpg_section/cpg_pressDetails.asp%3FpressNo%3D286 |archivedate=October 25, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and MADE Fashion Week,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://madefashionweek.com/ |title=MADE Fashion Week |publisher=MADE Fashion Week |work=madefashionweek.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-21}}</ref> and many independent fashion productions around town.<ref name="nymag.com">{{cite web |url=http://nymag.com/fashion/fashioncalendar/fashionweek/ |title=New York Fashion Week Schedule – Shows by Day and Designer |work=Nymag.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-21}}</ref>
Producers of New York Fashion Week include [[IMG (company)|IMG]], The SOCIETY Fashion Week, [[FTL Moda]] in conjunction with [[Fashion Week Online]], Style 360, Art Hearts Fashion, Style Fashion Week, and ASC Fashion week among others.<ref>{{cite web |title=NEW YORK FASHION WEEK PRODUCERS |url=http://fashionweekonline.com/new-york/producers |website=FWO |accessdate=7 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/madeline-stuart-down-syndrome-fashion-show_us_56c321b7e4b0b40245c7cc60 |title=Inspiring Model With Down Syndrome Returns To Fashion Week |work=The Huffington Post |date=February 17, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://mbfashionweek.com/designers/ftl-moda |title=Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week |website=mbfashionweek.com |access-date=2016-05-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fashionweekonline.com/new-york/producers|title=New York Fashion Week Producers {{!}} Fashion Week Online®|work=Fashion Week Online®|access-date=2018-06-05|language=en-US}}</ref>
A centralized calendar of citywide events (including those affiliated with WME/IMG) is kept by the CFDA,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cfda.com/the-latest/cfda-fashion-calendar |title=CFDA + Fashion Calendar |first= |last=CFDA |publisher=}}</ref> and was acquired from calendar founder [[Ruth Finley]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fashionweekdaily.com/the-cfda-acquires-ruth-finleys-fashion-calendar |title=The CFDA Purchases The Fashion Calendar With The Promise To Streamline Fashion Week |date=July 25, 2014 |work=fashionweekdaily.com}}</ref> Another calendar is kept by Fashion Week Online.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fashionweekonline.com/new-york/schedule|title=Official NYFW Schedule {{!}} Fashion Week Online®|work=Fashion Week Online®|access-date=2018-06-05|language=en-US}}</ref>
The economic impact of New York Fashion Week is estimated at $887 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cfda.com/blog/nyfw-memo-from-the-cfda |title=NYFW Memo from the CFDA |work=cfda.com}}</ref>
==Origin == The first New York Fashion Week was created in 1943 by [[Eleanor Lambert]], press director of the American fashion industry’s first promotional organization, the New York Dress Institute.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cfda.com/about/history |title=History |work=cfda.com}}</ref>
The event, the world's first organized [[fashion week]], was called "Press Week", and was created to attract attention away from French fashion during [[World War II]], when fashion industry insiders were unable to travel to Paris to see French fashion shows.<ref name="slate">{{cite web |last=Fortini |first=Amanda |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2135561 |title=A brief history of the fashion show |work=Slate.com |date=2006-02-08 |accessdate=2014-04-21}}</ref> It was also meant to showcase American designers for [[fashion journalism|fashion journalists]], who had neglected U.S. fashion innovations.
Press Week was a success, and fashion magazines like ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'', which were normally filled with French designs, increasingly featured American fashion.<ref name="slate" />
By the mid-1950s, the event was known as "Press Week of New York". Spring 1951 (held February 1951) was the 16th Annual Press Week of New York.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://inv.stparchive.com/Archive/INV/INV02011951P10.php |title=Indian Valley Record February 1, 1951 Page 10 |publisher=}}</ref>
== Consolidation as "7th on Sixth"== In 1993, the CFDA, led by president [[Stan Herman]] and executive director [[Fern Mallis]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://loewsmagazine.com/stan-herman/ |title=The People's Designer – Stan Herman |work=Loews Magazine |first=Louis |last=Chunovic |date=April 16, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://fashionista.com/2015/06/stan-herman-father-of-fashion-week |title=How Stan Herman, Father of Fashion Week, Changed the U.S. Fashion Industry |work=Fashionista |first=Chantal |last=Fernandez |date=June 29, 2015}}</ref> consolidated the citywide events known as "New York Fashion Week" by staging them in a cluster of white tents in [[Bryant Park]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Mell |first=Eila |date=2011 |title=New York Fashion Week: The Designers, the Models, the Fashions of the Bryant Park Era |url=https://www.amazon.com/New-York-Fashion-Week-Designers/dp/0762441917 |publisher=Running Press |page=10 |isbn=0762441917}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/09/fashion/fern-mallis-pitching-a-few-new-tents-of-her-own.html |title=Pitching a Few New Tents of Her Own |date=February 9, 2012 |work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Spindler |first=Amy |title=Designers Turn New York Into a Fashion Big Top |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/10/31/nyregion/designers-turn-new-york-into-a-fashion-big-top.html |work=The New York Times |date=October 31, 1993 |accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> The event was branded with the trademark "7th on Sixth."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.racked.com/2015/1/22/7560555/new-york-fashion-week-changes |title=The Glamorous Past, Troubled Present, and Uncertain Future of NYFW |first=Chavie |last=Lieber |date=January 22, 2015 |work=racked.com}}</ref>
==21st century== In 2001, "7th on Sixth" was sold to [[IMG (company)|IMG]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Horyn |first=Cathy |title=Front Row: Designers council sells sponsorship of New York Fashion Week to IMG, the sports management and marketing company |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/02/06/style/front-row-designers-council-sells-sponsorship-new-york-fashion-week-img-sports.html |work=The New York Times |date=February 6, 2001 |accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>
In 2004, the camera company Olympus became a sponsor of IMG's events, which were then renamed "Olympus Fashion Week."<ref name="olympusamerica.com" />
In 2007,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mbusa.com/mercedes/events/fashion |title=EventsPartnerships |publisher=}}</ref> Mercedes-Benz became title sponsor of the IMG-produced events, adding New York to its roster of international "Mercedes-Benz fashion weeks,"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mbfashionweek.com/ |title=Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week |work=mbfashionweek.com}}</ref> and dubbing it "MB Fashion Week New York."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/mercedes-threatens-bail-new-york-748286 |title=Mercedes Threatens to Bail on New York Fashion Week |work=hollywoodreporter.com}}</ref>
In 2010, IMG/Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week New York left the Bryant Park tents, relocating to the [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts]].<ref name="hollywoodreporter.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/new-york-fashion-week-is-759258 |title=It's Official: New York Fashion Week Is Leaving Lincoln Center |publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/03/fashion/03TENTS.html |title=A New Home for New York Fashion Week |date=February 3, 2009 |work=The New York Times}}</ref>
In September 2011, New York designers began live-streaming runway shows, following London, who began in February 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/news/london-fashion-week-to-be-streamed-live-1904888.html |title=London Fashion Week to be streamed live |date=February 19, 2010 |publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/08/fashion/live-streaming-of-runway-shows-new-york-fashion-week.html |title=Way Off the Runway: Live Streaming of Fashion Week |date=September 8, 2011 |work=The New York Times}}</ref> Streams were originally offered on YouTube, and later on other sites.
In 2013, IMG and its New York Fashion Week events were sold to [[William Morris Endeavor]] (WME) and Silver Lake Partners for $2.3 billion.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2015/02/wme-img-merger-ari-emanuel |title=Ari Emanuel’s Risky and Possibly Catastrophic WME-IMG Merger |first=William D. |last=Cohan |work=vanityfair.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://img.com/news/news/2013/decembmer/img-worldwide-to-be-acquired-by-silver-lake-partne.aspx |title=IMG WORLDWIDE TO BE ACQUIRED BY SILVER LAKE PARTNERS AND WILLIAM MORRIS ENDEAVOR |work=IMG |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150704065440/http://img.com/news/news/2013/decembmer/img-worldwide-to-be-acquired-by-silver-lake-partne.aspx |archivedate=July 4, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In 2014, the CFDA acquired FashionCalendar.com from [[Ruth Finley]], who had managed it (originally in paper, then digital format) for more than 60 years.<ref>http://fashionista.com/2014/07/cfda-acquires-fashion-calendar</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://fashioncalendar.com/about-us/ |title=Fashion Calendar |work=fashioncalendar.com}}</ref>
In January 2015, Mercedes-Benz announced its departure as title sponsor from WME/IMG's events.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/img-loses-mercedes-as-fashion-761135 |title=IMG Loses Mercedes as New York Fashion Week Sponsor |work=hollywoodreporter.com}}</ref> Producer Kanye West announced he would gladly take over sponsorship of the event.{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}}
In March 2015, WME/IMG announced that it had acquired MADE Fashion Week, which takes place during WME/IMG's events.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2015/biz/news/wme-img-acquires-made-fashion-week-1201458187/ |title=IMG Acquires MADE Fashion Week |first=Marianne |last=Zumberge |date=March 23, 2015 |work=IMG}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://img.com/news/news/2015/march/wme---img-acquires-made-fashion-week.aspx |title=IIMG ACQUIRES MADE FASHION WEEK |work=IMG |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150704131015/http://img.com/news/news/2015/march/wme---img-acquires-made-fashion-week.aspx |archivedate=July 4, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In 2015, IMG's events were moved from Lincoln Center to Spring Studios.<ref name="hollywoodreporter.com" /><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/08/fashion/for-fashion-week-this-fall-location-location-location.html |title=For Fashion Week This Fall: Location, Location, Location |date=January 8, 2015 |work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-features/new-york-fashion-week-lincoln-center-10108237/ |title=New York Fashion Week Leaves Lincoln Center |first=Lisa |last=Lockwood |date=April 13, 2015 |publisher=}}</ref>
==Current location== Following the loss of Bryant Park and later Lincoln Center as hosting site for New York Fashion Week, the event is no longer held in one central location. Locations have included a waterfront carnival, converted railway terminals and a former post office.<ref>https://www.amny.com/lifestyle/fashion-week/new-york-fashion-week-when-where-what-to-wear-1.10833995</ref>
==Other notable events== [[File:NYFashionWeekSep2008Front.jpg|thumb|right|Outside entrance, Spring 2009 New York Fashion Week]]
=== 2014 === In February 2014, Dr. Danielle Sheypuk became the first wheelchair-using model to appear in a show for New York Fashion Week; she modeled for designer Carrie Hammer.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lankston |first=Charlie |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2988789/Woman-history-wheelchair-bound-model-appear-New-York-Fashion-Week-lands-debut-clothing-campaign.html |title=Dr. Danielle Sheypuk the first wheelchair-bound model in NYFW lands her debut clothing campaign |work=Daily Mail |date= |accessdate=2015-03-12}}</ref>
In September 2014, Karen Crespo became the first quadruple-amputee to walk at New York Fashion Week, also for Carrie Hammer. <ref>{{cite web |author=Jessica Probus |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/jessicaprobus/a-quadruple-amputee-walked-the-runway-at-new-york-fashion-we#.qiQB3rpm3 |title=A Quadruple Amputee Walked The Runway At New York Fashion Week |work=Buzzfeed.com |date=2015-03-07 |accessdate=2015-03-12}}</ref>
On December 12, 2014, a New York state court approved a settlement in a lawsuit by community activists over whether allowing the Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week tents in [[Damrosch Park]] was a violation of the [[public trust doctrine]]. In accordance with the settlement, the City of New York, the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, and [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts]] agreed not to renew their contract with IMG. As a result, the February 2015 Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week was the last one staged in Damrosch Park.<ref>{{cite news |title=New York Fashion Week Booted Out of Lincoln Center |url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2014/12/18/business/ap-us-fashion-week-booted.html |work=The New York Times |date=December 18, 2014 |accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>
=== 2015 === The fall/winter 2015 shows took place from February 12–19.<ref>{{cite web |title=Fashion Calendar |url=http://nymag.com/fashion/fashioncalendar/fashionweek/ |publisher=New York Mag |accessdate=July 2, 2015}}</ref> In that week, actress [[Jamie Brewer]] became the first woman with [[Down syndrome]] to walk the red carpet at New York Fashion Week, which she did for designer Carrie Hammer.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/stephaniemcneal/meet-the-first-woman-with-down-syndrome-to-walk-at-fashion-w#.rdlZWQNlK |title=Meet The First Woman With Down Syndrome To Walk At Fashion Week |author=Jessica Probus, Stephanie McNeal |work=BuzzFeed}}</ref>
The spring/summer 2016<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.instyle.com/news/new-york-fashion-week-schedule-spring-summer-2016-nyfw |title=Here's the New York Fashion Week Spring/Summer 2016 Schedule |publisher=}}</ref> shows took place from September 10–17, 2015 at two new locations, Skylight at Moynihan Station in Midtown and Skylight Clarkson Square in SoHo.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Mau |first1=Dhani |title=New York Fashion Week Is Moving To Two New Locations |url=http://fashionista.com/2015/04/new-york-fashion-week-new-venues |website=fashionista.com |accessdate=July 2, 2015}}</ref> The economic impact of these shows was estimated to be $900 million and attendance was approximately 125,000 people.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Anwar |first1=Sara |title=From staged stumbles to transatlantic shifts: This was NYC Fashion Week |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/09/18/fashion/new-york-fashion-week-wrap-nyfw/ |publisher=CNN |accessdate=October 26, 2015}}</ref>
In December 2015, the CFDA announced that it had hired the Boston Consulting Group to study revising the format of New York Fashion Week to adapt to changes brought about by social media. One option being explored is to bifurcate the event, with private showroom appointments of next season's designs for buyers and public fashion shows displaying in-season merchandise for consumers.<ref>{{cite web |last=Lockwood |first=Lisa |title=NYFW Going Consumer? CFDA Studies Idea |url=http://wwd.com/fashion-news/designer-luxury/cfda-boston-consulting-fashion-shows-consumer-10297602/ |publisher=[[Women's Wear Daily]] |accessdate=December 16, 2015}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{cite web |url=http://cfda.com/blog/the-results-are-in-examining-the-future-of-new-york-fashion-week |title=The Results are in: Examining the Future of New York Fashion Week |first= |last=CFDA |publisher=}}</ref><ref>http://fashionista.com/2016/03/cfda-bcg-fashion-week-survey</ref>
The first New York Fashion Week dedicated menswear shows, called "New York Fashion Week: Men's," were produced by the CFDA in 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cfda.com/programs/new-york-mens-week |title=Full Coverage of NYFW: Men’s S/S 2017 |first= |last=CFDA |publisher=}}</ref>
=== 2016 === Fall/winter 2016 events took place February 11–18, 2016<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newyorkfashionweeklive.com/schedule |title=NYFW Schedule – New York Fashion Week |publisher=}}</ref> at a variety of locations around New York City, including Skylight Moynihan, Skylight Clarkson, Chelsea Piers, MADE Studios, and showrooms around town.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wwd.com/runway/fall-ready-to-wear-2016/new-york/ |title=2016 Fall Ready-to-Wear – WWD |publisher=}}</ref>
The season ended with a number of designers either experimenting with, or planning to adopt, a "see now, buy now model," with items available from the runway immediately after (or even during) the show, rather than six months later.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.harpersbazaar.com/fashion/fashion-week-fall-2016/news/a14169/fashion-week-changes/ |title=Is This The Last Traditional New York Fashion Week? |date=February 14, 2016 |publisher=}}</ref> The charge was led by brands such as [[Burberry]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/05/fashion/burberry-announces-a-see-now-buy-now-system-for-new-collections.html |title=Burberry Announces a See Now/Buy Now System for New Collections |date=February 6, 2016 |work=The New York Times}}</ref> although experiments in the format can be traced back to earlier shows by designers such as [[Diane von Furstenberg]].
Spring/summer 2017 events will be held September 8–15, 2016. (Fashion weeks are traditionally named for the season the clothes will appear at retail, six months after the events, although the trend may be changing due to fundamental shifts in the retail cycle.)<ref name="auto" />
The advent of "see now, buy now" shopping is expected to further transform fashion week, as collections become "in season" and select items are offered from the runway in real time.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.harpersbazaar.com/fashion/fashion-week-fall-2016/news/a14169/fashion-week-changes/ |title=Is This The Last Traditional New York Fashion Week? |date=2016-02-14 |website=Harper's BAZAAR |access-date=2016-04-27}}</ref>
=== 2018 === Fall/winter took place February 5-8, 2018, and spring/summer 2019 will take place September 6-14, 2018. In February, major venues were Spring Studios, among others.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nyfw.com/schedule-february-8-2018|title=Schedule: February 8, 2018|work=NYFW: The Shows|access-date=2018-06-05|language=en}}</ref>
==Attendance== Admission to shows at New York Fashion Week is typically in the form of [[accreditation]], with specific events by invitation only.<ref>{{cite web |last=Chan |first=Sewell |title=Fashion Week: Not Open to the Public |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/09/06/fashion-week-not-open-to-the-public |work=The New York Times |date=September 6, 2007 |accessdate=December 18, 2014}}</ref>
==No "Official" New York Fashion Week== In spite of CFDA's claim to run the "official" New York Fashion Week calendar,<ref>https://cfda.com/fashion-calendar/official-schedules</ref> and as further purported by publications such as ''[[Women's Wear Daily]]'',<ref>http://wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-scoops/the-tentative-official-nyfw-calendar-is-here-10953303/</ref> it has been pointed out in publications such as ''The Fashion Law'' that CFDA has "little, in any, legal rights in the NYFW name".<ref>http://www.thefashionlaw.com/home/the-cfda-has-little-if-any-rights-in-the-nyfw-name</ref> Therefore, trademark rights remain unclear, at best.
==Trademark litigation== In 2013 Fashion Week Inc., founded by Trisha Paravas, registered the [[trademark]]s “New York Fashion Week,” “NYFW”, and “NYFW The Runway Shows” to use in conjunction with the production of its consumer-based fashion shows. On June 28, 2016 Fashion Week Inc. filed a lawsuit for $10 million against [[Council of Fashion Designers of America|CFDA]] and [[WME-IMG]] for trademark counterfeiting, [[trademark infringement]], [[false designation of origin]], dilution, and [[unfair competition]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cullins |first1=A |title=WME-IMG and CFDA Facing $10M Lawsuit for "Usurping" New York Fashion Week Trademark. |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/wme-img-cfda-facing-10m-908838 |website=The Hollywood Reporter |accessdate=August 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Hoshikawa |first1=K |title=The CFDA is being sued over 'NYFW' trademark |url=http://fashionista.com/2016/07/cfda-nyfw-trademark-lawsuit |website=Fashionista |accessdate=August 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Drain |first1=K |title=New York Fashion Week Logo Lawsuit: CFDA, WME-IMG Sued |url=http://www.fashiontimes.com/articles/26917/20160706/new-york-fashion-week-logo-lawsuit-cfda-wme-img-sued.htm |website=Fashion Times |accessdate=August 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=The CFDA Has Little – If Any – Legal Rights in the NYFW Name |url=http://www.thefashionlaw.com/home/the-cfda-has-little-if-any-rights-in-the-nyfw-name |website=The Fashion Law |accessdate=August 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=UPDATED: CFDA, WME-IMG Sued for Using New York Fashion Week Trademark |url=http://www.thefashionlaw.com/home/the-cfda-wme-img-sued-over-new-york-fashion-week-trademark |website=The Fashion Law |accessdate=August 3, 2016}}</ref>
On August 12, 2016, the court denied Fashion Week Inc.'s motion for a [[preliminary injunction]].<ref name=hballp>{{Cite web |url=http://hballp.com/wp-content/uploads/PI-decision.pdf |title=Memorandum Opinion and Order |last= |first= |date=August 12, 2016 |website= |publisher= |access-date=}}</ref> Judge Koeltl held that CFDA and WME-IMG made "a persuasive argument that the terms 'New York Fashion Week' and NYFW have been associated with them and not with [Fashion Week Inc.] who has attempted to cash in on the decades of publicity for New York Fashion Week that [Fashion Week Inc.] had nothing to do with."<ref name=hballp />{{rp|22}} The court also noted that "the evidence shows that [Fashion Week Inc.] produced at most two shows while using the trademark 'New York Fashion Week', and has produced no shows since registering NYFW in December 2015. "<ref name=hballp />{{rp|24}}

{{Infobox song | name = New York Mining Disaster 1941 | cover = New_York_Mining_Disaster_1941.gif | alt = | border = yes | type = single | artist = [[Bee Gees]] | album = [[Bee Gees' 1st]] | B-side = "[[I Can't See Nobody]]"{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Bee-Gees-The-New-York-Mining-Disaster-1941/release/2603864 |title=Bee Gees - New York Mining Disaster 1941 |publisher=Discogs |accessdate=13 March 2013}} | released = 14 April 1967 | format = [[7"]] | recorded = {{plainlist|13–16 March 1967|[[IBC Studios]], London}} | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Folk rock]]{{cite book|author=Nicholas Pegg|title=The Complete David Bowie|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nnO_BgAAQBAJ&pg=PT730|accessdate=25 November 2015|date=2 December 2011|publisher=Titan|isbn=978-0-85768-719-7|page=730}} | length = {{Duration|m=2|s=09}} | label = [[Polydor Records|Polydor]] (United Kingdom, Canada)
[[Atco Records|Atco]] (United States, Mexico)
[[Spin Records (Australian Label)|Spin]] (Australia, New Zealand) | writer = [[Barry Gibb]], [[Robin Gibb]] | producer = [[Robert Stigwood]], [[Ossie Byrne]] | prev_title = Born a Man | prev_year = 1967 | next_title = [[To Love Somebody (song)|To Love Somebody]] | next_year = 1967 | misc = {{Extra music sample|filename=NewYorkMiningDisaster1941.ogg |title="New York Mining Disaster 1941" |Type=single}} }} '''"New York Mining Disaster 1941"''' is the debut American single by the British pop group the [[Bee Gees]], released on 14 April 1967. It was written by [[Barry Gibb|Barry]] and [[Robin Gibb]]. Barring a moderately successful reissue of their Australian single "[[Spicks and Specks (song)|Spicks and Specks]]," it was the first single release of the group's international career and their first song to hit the charts in both the UK and the US. It was produced by [[Ossie Byrne]] with their manager [[Robert Stigwood]] as executive producer. The song was the first track of side two on the group's international debut album, ''[[Bee Gees' 1st]].'' This was the first single with Australian drummer [[Colin Petersen]] as an official member of the band. ==Background and writing== On 3 January 1967, the Gibb brothers, with their parents and Byrne, set sail from Australia to England on the ship [[Fairsky]], reaching Southampton on 6 February. The brothers performed on board in exchange for passage. Later, the Gibb brothers auditioned for Stigwood; they passed, and they signed to [[RSO Records|Robert Stigwood Organisation]] on 24 February. "New York Mining Disaster 1941" was their first song that was written in 1967. The first recording session of the Bee Gees after returning to England was a second version of "[[Town of Tuxley Toymaker, Part 1]]," a song recorded by [[Billy J. Kramer|Billy J. Kramer and the Dakotas]], but was first recorded by Jon Blanchfield in Australia. Kramer's version was recorded on 4 March 1967 in [[IBC Studios]], London, with the Gibb brothers on background vocals. Barry and Robin Gibb wrote the song while sitting on a darkened staircase at [[Polydor Records]] following a power cut. The echo of the passing lift inspired them to imagine that they were trapped in a mine.{{cite web|url=http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=7494 |title=New York Mining Disaster 1941 (Songfacts) |publisher=Songfacts |accessdate=13 March 2013}} The song recounts the story of a miner trapped in a cave-in. He is sharing a photo of his wife with a colleague ("Mr. Jones") while they hopelessly wait to be rescued.{{cite web|url= http://www.allmusic.com/song/new-york-mining-disaster-1941-mt0030257568 |title=Bee Gees - New York Mining Disaster 1941 |last=Elias |first=Jason |work=[[Allmusic]] |publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]] |accessdate=13 March 2013}} According to the liner notes for their box-set ''[[Tales from the Brothers Gibb]]'' (1990), this song was inspired by the 1966 [[Aberfan disaster|Aberfan mining disaster]] in [[Wales]]. According to Robin, there actually had also been a mining disaster in New York in 1939, but not in 1941.{{cite web|url=http://www.brothersgibb.org/history-part-4.html |title=History Part 4 - The story about the Bee Gees |last=Adriaensen |first=Marion |accessdate=13 March 2013}} In the second and third verses, the lyrical lines get slower and slower, as if to indicate that life is about to end for the miners. On the second chorus, the drums get louder. On the second verse, when Robin sings the line "I keep straining my ears to hear a sound," a violin was featured in response on Robin's line. ==Recording and composition== [[File:NYMiningdisaster68sheet.png|thumb|left|1967 sheet music cover, Abigail Music, Ltd., London. "Recorded by the Bee Gees on Polydor".]] On 7 March, the Bee Gees recorded "New York Mining Disaster 1941" in six takes, along with three other songs: "[[I Can't See Nobody]]," "Red Chair, Fade Away," and "Turn of the Century." The orchestra and some other parts were added on 13 March.{{cite web|url= http://www.columbia.edu/~brennan/beegees/67.html |title=Gibb Songs: 1967 |last=Brennan |first=Joseph |accessdate=13 March 2013}} "New York Mining Disaster 1941" was done first, and it may have already been nominated as the first single on the strength of the Polydor demo. The song begins in the chord of A minor; as Maurice explained: "There's a lot of weird sounds on this song like the Jew's harp, the string quartet, and of course the special way that Barry plays that guitar chord. Because of his tuning when he plays the minor at the beginning of the song which is different from a conventional A minor, it's a nice mixture when I play my conventional tuning together with Barry's tuning because his [[Open D tuning|open D]] and mine are different." Barry said, "It's Hawaiian tuning, there they play the same way I do. I got a guitar for my ninth birthday and the guy who lived across the road from us just came back from Hawaii and he was the one who taught me that tuning, that's how it started and I never changed." Robin Gibb took both leading and backing vocals, singing the high harmony while Barry sang the low harmony on the first and second verse: [[Maurice Gibb]] recalled in a June 2001 interview with ''[[Mojo (magazine)|Mojo]]'' magazine: "The opening chord doesn't sound like a conventional A minor. Barry was using the open D tuning he'd been taught when he was nine, and I was playing it in conventional tuning. It gives an unusual blend. People went crazy trying to figure out why they couldn't copy it." Robin Gibb recalled to ''The Mail on Sunday'' on November 1, 2009: "We recorded this at London's IBC studio because it was dark and emulated a mining shaft. The result was a very lonely sound." ==Release and reception== At the time, rumours circulated that the Bee Gees were [[The Beatles]] recording under a pseudonym (the Bee Gees' name was alleged to be code for "Beatles Group"), in part because the record referenced NEMS Enterprises ([[Brian Epstein]]'s management agency, which had just been joined by Bee Gees' manager [[Robert Stigwood]]). The song is unusual in that the lyrics do not contain the song's title, though the originally planned title, "Have You Seen My Wife, Mr. Jones," does appear in the chorus.{{cite web|url=https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc19826/m1/ |title=Show 49 - The British are Coming! The British are Coming!: With an emphasis on Donovan, the Bee Gees and the Who. (Part 6) |publisher=Unt Digital Library |accessdate=14 March 2013}} [[Atco Records|Atco]] distributed promos with a blank label and the suggestion that it was an English group whose name started with B. Many [[Disc jockey|DJ]]s thought it was a new Beatles song and played the song heavily. Atco also retitled the song "New York Mining Disaster 1941 (Have You Seen My Wife, Mr. Jones?)" to make sure people could find it in the shops.{{cite web |url=http://britishinvasionbands.com/the-bands/the-bee-gees/?doing_wp_cron=1363251960.7064080238342285156250 |title=The Bee Gees on British Invasion Bands |publisher=British Invasion |accessdate=14 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022175804/http://britishinvasionbands.com/the-bands/the-bee-gees/?doing_wp_cron=1363251960.7064080238342285156250 |archivedate=22 October 2014 |df= }} [[The Beatles|Beatles]] lead guitarist [[George Harrison]] met Maurice Gibb at a party several years later, and told him that he had bought a copy of "New York Mining Disaster 1941" because he thought it sounded so much like The Beatles. Maurice's response to Harrison was that the resemblance "was unintentional" and Harrison said, "I knew that, I admire your work."{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KugbDQHX0R8C&pg=PT258&dq=new+york+mining+disaster+1941+they+can+tell+the+beatles&hl=fil&sa=X&ei=nuvTULrrGaeiigeQrYCAAg&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAQ |title=The Bee Gees - Tales Of The Brothers Gibb |last=Hughes |first=Andrew |accessdate=21 December 2012}} Barry Gibb explained about this song:
"If you sounded like the Beatles and also could write a hit single, then the hype of the machine would go into action, and your company would make sure people thought you sounded like the Beatles or thought you were the Beatles. And that sold you, attracted attention to you. It was good for us because everyone thought it was the Beatles under a different name."
Robin Gibb explained about this track:
"...all the DJs on radio stations in the US picked it up immediately thinking it was the Beatles, and it was a hit on that basis. It established us in those early years. It helped our following record which was nothing like the Beatles."
The success of this song owes a lot more to the perseverance of Robert Stigwood than he has previously been given credit for. "We had quite a hard time at getting the Bee Gees played. We weren't all totally convinced that Stigwood was picking the right song to plug, but at the end of the day, he was a forceful character. All of these guys were... [[Chas Chandler]] (manager of [[Jimi Hendrix]]) was the same, [[Kit Lambert]] (manager of [[The Who]]) was the same. They all argued their case with passion, you know, they lived it, they were like that," conceded [[Polydor Records|Polydor]]'s [[Alan Bates]]. When the ''Disc & Music Echo'' reported "widespread rumours" that this song had been written by [[Lennon-McCartney|Lennon and McCartney]], Robin countered with, "Rubbish! We've always written our own songs. I've been writing since I was ten, before Lennon and McCartney were even on stage. People can say what they like. If they don't believe us, they can ask The Beatles." Bassist Maurice Gibb, though, had previously said that "New York Mining Disaster 1941" was in fact influenced by the Beatles:
"New York Mining Disaster 1941" was a total rip-off of The Beatles, we were so influenced by them. In fact it started a mystery [in the USA] about us, because they started playing [it] and saying, 'They're this new group from England that begins with a B and finished with an s' so they all said, 'Ah, it's The Beatles, not naming it, they're doing that trick again.' The disc jockey would play it and play it and play it and, 'Guess who it is?' and people would guess, and they wouldn't get the answer. I heard [the idea] came actually from [[Ahmet Ertegun]] and [[Jerry Wexler]]. To us it was an honour, to actually think we were as good as The Beatles."
==Music video and live performances== On the video, the band only features four members (but [[Vince Melouney]] later joined the band), Barry playing his guitar, Maurice playing his [[Rickenbacker 4001]], Robin Gibb on vocals and drummer [[Colin Petersen]] wears a hat.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ps-Qq7ucMA0 |title=Bee Gees - New York Mining Disaster 1941 (1967) |publisher=You Tube |accessdate=14 July 2013}} The group found time to record their first BBC session at Playhouse Theatre, Northumberland Avenue, London, with producer Bill Bebb, on which they performed this song, with the songs "In My Own Time," "One Minute Woman," and "Cucumber Castle." When the BBC Light Programme's ''Saturday Club'' presented by Brian Matthew was broadcast on April 22, it was noted that there were "rave reviews from the audition panel." On the song's promotional clip, the band only feature four members (the three Gibb brothers and drummer [[Colin Petersen]]) The group (Barry, Robin, Maurice, Colin and Vince) made their first British TV appearance on ''Top of the Pops'' performing this song on May 11 and were rather awe-struck at the company they were keeping. On 20 May 1967, the group performed this song on ''[[Beat-Club]],'' a German TV program. The Bee Gees performed this song on 21 July 1967 at the Stockholm Palladium, Stockholm, Sweden., 12 August 1967 at The Civic Hall, Wolverhampton, England and Christ the King College at Newport, England on 27 September 1967. Since 1967, the song has been part of every Bee Gees concert, eventually becoming part of their acoustic medley performed during the middle of the concert. It was also performed on the show ''[[Beat-Club]]'' in [[Germany]], on that performance Robin wears a hat and plays [[violin]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UlSLDUGKWEc |title=Bee Gees - New York Mining Disaster 1941 Live in Beat Club |publisher=You Tube |accessdate=14 July 2013}} It was performed by the group in 1973 on ''[[The Midnight Special (TV series)|The Midnight Special]]'' with Barry and Maurice on rhythm guitar.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hZ5tSc3tqOE |title=Bee Gees - New York Mining Disaster - live, 1973 |publisher=You Tube |accessdate=14 July 2013}} ==Personnel== * [[Robin Gibb]] – [[Lead vocalist|lead vocals]] * [[Barry Gibb]] – [[Backing vocalist|harmony]] and backing vocals, [[rhythm guitar]] * [[Maurice Gibb]] – [[bass guitar]], rhythm guitar, backing vocals * [[Colin Petersen]] – [[Drum kit|drums]] * Phil Dennys – orchestral arrangement The session was engineered by Carlos Olms and produced by Robert Stigwood. ==Charts== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Weekly charts=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !Chart (1967) !Peak
position |- |Australia ([[Kent Music Report]]){{cite web|url=http://www.brothersgibb.org/download/page-1.pdf |title=Songs Written by the Gibb Family on the International Charts |publisher=brothersgibb.org |accessdate=18 January 2015}} | style="text-align:center;"|11 |- |Canada Top Singles (''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'') | style="text-align:center;"|34 |- |France ([[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique|SNEP]]) | style="text-align:center;"|36 |- |Germany ([[Media Control Charts]]){{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.de/song.asp?artist=Bee+Gees&title=New+York+Mining+Disaster+1941&country=de |title=Bee Gees - New York Mining Disaster 1941 |publisher=officialcharts.de |accessdate=18 January 2015}} | style="text-align:center;"|10 |- |Netherlands ([[Dutch Top 40]]){{cite web|url=http://dutchcharts.nl/showitem.asp?interpret=Bee+Gees&titel=New+York+Mining+Disaster+1941&cat=s |title=Bee Gees - New York Mining Disaster 1941 |publisher=Dutch Charts |accessdate=18 January 2015}} | style="text-align:center;"|3 |- |New Zealand ([[Recorded Music NZ]]) | style="text-align:center;"|3 |- |UK Singles ([[Official Charts Company]]){{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/_/bee%20gees/ |title=Bee Gees - Chart History |publisher=Official Charts Company |accessdate=18 January 2015}} | style="text-align:center;"|12 |- |US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/281091/bee-gees/chart?page=4&f=379 |title=Bee Gees - Chart History |publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |accessdate=18 January 2015}} | style="text-align:center;"|14 |- |US ''[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cash Box]]''{{cite web |url=http://50.6.195.142/archives/60s_files/19670701.html |title=Cashbox Charts |date=July 1, 1967 |publisher=Cashbox Magazine Archives |accessdate=18 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131229202650/http://50.6.195.142/archives/60s_files/19670701.html |archivedate=29 December 2013 |df= }} | style="text-align:center;"|17 |- |US ''[[Record World]]'' | style="text-align:center;"|14 |} {{col-2}} ===Year-end charts=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !Chart (1967) !Position |- |Netherlands ([[Dutch Top 40]]) | style="text-align:center;"|17 |} {{col-end}} ==Legacy== The 1969 [[David Bowie]] song "[[Space Oddity]]" owes a debt to the style, arrangement and lyrics of "New York Mining Disaster 1941." Like "New York Mining Disaster 1941," "Space Oddity" is about a trapped man who is doomed to die, and the song is similarly structured as a series of statements addressed to another person. "'Space Oddity' was a Bee Gees type song," Bowie’s colleague John "Hutch" Hutchinson has said. "David knew it, and he said so at the time, the way he sang it, it’s a Bee Gees thing."{{cite web |url=http://davidbowie.com/users/lunamagic/space1.html |title=David Bowie - Space Oddity |accessdate=13 March 2013 }}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} As [[Marc Bolan]] explained: "I remember David playing me 'Space Oddity' in his room and I loved it and he said he needed a sound like the Bee Gees, who were very big then." [[Paul McCartney]] said: "It was the 'Mining Disaster' song that [Robert Stigwood] played me. I said 'sign them, they're great!' And they went on to be even greater."{{cite web |url=http://www14.brinkster.com/corteza/bg/citas.htm |title=Bee Gees |publisher=14.brinkster.com |accessdate=2014-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230235737/http://www14.brinkster.com/corteza/bg/citas.htm |archivedate=2013-12-30 |df= }} The Japanese Novelist [[Haruki Murakami]] made "New York Mining Disaster" the title of one of his short stories. The piece was included in his collection "[[Blind Willow, Sleeping Woman]]".{{cite web|last=Umrigar |first=Thrity |url=http://www.boston.com/ae/books/articles/2006/10/01/murakami_pulls_mind_bending_stories_from_the_ruins_of_broken_rules/ |title=Murakami pulls mind-bending stories from the ruins of broken rules - The Boston Globe |website=Boston.com |date=2006-10-01 |accessdate=2016-07-27}} ==Cover versions== * In early 1969, [[The Sorrows]] recorded this song as part of a demo album that was prepared before the release of their second album ''Old Songs New Songs''; however, the song remained unreleased until it was included in a two-CD reissue of that album by Wooden Hill in 2009. * In 1969, [[Ashton, Gardner and Dyke]] recorded a version of this song for their self-titled debut album. * In 1974, [[Barclay James Harvest]] "deconstructed" the song with a reworked version referencing leading figures in the [[Three-Day Week|1974 UK mining strike]]. The song was retitled "The Great 1974 Mining Disaster."{{cite web|url=http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=8023 |title=The Great 1974 Mining Disaster by Barclay James Harvest Songfacts |publisher=Songfacts.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-07}} * In 1993, [[David Essex]] recorded a version of this song for his covers album ''Cover Shot.'' * In 1997, the [[Levellers (band)|Levellers]] covered the song as a B-side to their single ''Bozos.'' * In 1998, folksinger [[Martin Carthy]] sang an acoustic guitar version of this as the lead-off track on his album ''Signs of Life.'' * In 2000, British anarchist band [[Chumbawamba]] recorded a "[[minimalist]]" version for their album ''[[WYSIWYG (album)|WYSIWYG]].'' * In 2006, Mark Newman recorded a version of "New York Mining Disaster, 1941" on his CD ''Must Be A Pony,'' which he released on Danal Music. * In 2008, singer-songwriter [[Trevor Tanner]] released a version titled ''Mr. Jones'' on his album ''Eaten By The Sea.'' * In 2011, Australian bush punk act Handsome Young Strangers covered the song as a B-side to their single ''Sweet As A Nut'' and then included it on their album ''Here's The Thunder Lads!'' * In 2011 British Folk artist [[Jon Boden]] (of folk big Band [[Bellowhead]]) released an unaccompanied version as part of his "A Folk Song a Day" Project. * In 2012, the Catalina Scramblers, a three-piece rock band from Santa Cruz, CA, recorded a version of the song in which they adhere to the original version's style for the verses, but perform the choruses in up-tempo, hard rock fashion. It was released as the final track on their eponymous debut album. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{YouTube|ps-Qq7ucMA0|Official music video of the song}} *[http://www.brothersgibb.org/history-part-4.html History of the song] *[https://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/13716838/review/13750860/the_studio_albums_19671968 Rolling Stone Review] *[{{Allmusic|class=song|id=t3116604|pure_url=yes}} AMG Review] * {{MetroLyrics song|bee-gees|new-york-mining-disaster-1941}} {{Bee Gees}} {{Bee Gees singles}} [[Category:Bee Gees songs]] [[Category:1967 singles]] [[Category:1967 songs]] [[Category:Songs about New York (state)]] [[Category:Songs written by Barry Gibb]] [[Category:Songs written by Robin Gibb]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Robert Stigwood]] [[Category:Folk rock songs]] [[Category:Polydor Records singles]] [[Category:Atco Records singles]] [[Category:Spin Records (Australian label) singles]] [[Category:Songs based on actual events]] [[Category:Works about mining]]

revision.text:
'''Operation Anti Sexual Harassment''', (Arabic: قوة ضد التحرش, transliterated: Quwwa did al-taharrush, also known as OpAntiSH) is an activist group in Cairo, Egypt, whose goal is to prevent [[sexual harassment]] and assault, and in particular the [[Mass sexual assault in Egypt|mass sexual assaults]] that occur during protests and religious festivals. The group is known for intervening in assaults by mobs in Cairo's [[Tahrir Square]] and is one of several that have begun to organize against sexual harassment of women in Tahrir since the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]].<ref name=DailyNews>{{cite web|last=Hegab|first=Salma|date=27 January 2013|title=19 Sexual Harassment cases in Tahrir, Sky News reporter assaulted in Alexandria|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/01/27/19-sexual-harassment-cases-in-tahrir-sky-news-reporter-assaulted-in-alexandria/|publisher=Daily News Egypt|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref><ref name=Guardian>{{cite web|last=Kingsley|first=Patrick|date=27 January 2013|title=Tahrir Square sexual assaults reported during anniversary clashes|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jan/27/tahrir-square-sexual-assaults-reported|publisher=Guardian|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref>
==Background== {{further|Mass sexual assault in Egypt}} Although sexual harassment in the streets of Egypt predates the 2011 revolution, and is thought to have been a tactic of the Mubarak-era state used against female activists since 2005, reported cases of group sexual assaults during demonstrations in Tahrir square have been on the rise since 2011.<ref name=Guardian /><ref name=Monitor /> The first to gain international attention was South African reporter [[Lara Logan]], who was sexually assaulted by a gang of men on 11 February 2011, the night of Mubarak's resignation.<ref name=WeN /> It has been reported that at least 25 women were sexually assaulted in Tahrir during [[Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Mohamed Morsi (from November 2012)#January|protests in January 2013]] on the occasion of the revolution's two-year anniversary.<ref name=Guardian /> In accounts collected by OpAntiSh and other groups and some published in social media, women describe being stripped, beaten, molested and raped.<ref name=DailyNews /><ref name=Guardian /><ref name=WeN />
While some attacks appear to be spontaneous and stem from [[mob mentality]], OpAntiSH activists believe that at least some of the sexual assaults are planned and carried out by organized gangs, to keep women from participating in the revolution's protests in Tahrir square.<ref name=Guardian /><ref name=Monitor /><ref name=WeN /><ref name=EgyptInd1 /> They point to the timing and patterns of the attacks and persistence of the harassers when confronted. Dalia Abdel Hameed, of the Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights (EIPR) has said, “The easiest way to punish women in this country is through sexuality. In a culture that blames the victim, women start to believe that they shouldn’t go to the square.”<ref name=Monitor />
==Organization== OpAntiSH was established in November 2012 by volunteers, including those affiliated with [[Tamer El Said#Mosireen|Mosireen]], an Egyptian revolutionary media group.<ref name=Guardian /><ref name=EgyptInd1>{{cite web|last=Charbel|first=Jano |date=8 December 2012|title=Hands off: Initiatives grow fighting sexual harassment in Tahrir and elsewhere|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/hands-initiatives-grow-fighting-sexual-harassment-tahrir-and-elsewhere|publisher=Egypt Independent|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref> OpAntiSH first appeared in Tahrir Square on 30 November 2012, during [[2012 Egyptian protests|protests]] against President [[Mohamed Morsi]]'s [[Mohamed Morsi#November 2012 declaration|constitutional declaration]], alongside groups like [[Banat Misr Khatt Ahmar]] (Egypt’s Girls Are a Red Line), which was founded earlier in 2012.<ref name=EgyptInd1 /> OpAntiSH's campaigns against sexual harassment are supported by a coalition of organizations like [[Harassmap]], which collects and maps crowd-sourced data about sexual harassment in Egypt, and [[Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights]], a human rights organization founded in 2002.<ref name=DailyNews /><ref name=WeN>{{cite web|last=Gray|first=Jessica|date=25 January 2013|title=Egyptians Patrol Tahrir Square for Mob Sex Assaults|url=http://womensenews.org/story/sexual-harassment/130124/egyptians-patrol-tahrir-square-mob-sex-assaults#.UQW-JqFQBjY|publisher=Women's eNews Inc|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref><ref name=EgyptInd2>{{cite web|last=Dale|first=Tom |date=27 January 2013|title=Sexual assault in Tahrir: What it means, and how to stop it|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/opinion/sexual-assault-tahrir-what-it-means-and-how-stop-it|publisher=Egypt Independent|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref> OpAntiSH's slogan is "A safe square for all."<ref name=EgyptInd1 /> The group continues to gather new volunteers, some joining to help protect others after being rescued from [[sexual assault]] themselves.<ref name=EgyptInd2 />
==Methods== OpAntiSH uses a variety of methods to combat sexual harassment, in attempts to remove barriers to women's participation in street protests by keeping them physically and emotionally safe.<ref name=Monitor>{{cite web|last=El Sirgany|first=Sarah|date=7 December 2012|title=In Egypt, Women Lead Fight Against Mob Sexual Assaults|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2012/al-monitor/egypt-sexual-harrassment.html|publisher=Al Monitor|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref> Volunteers in the group conduct outreach and publicity to raise awareness of sexual harassment, and provide legal, medical, and psychological support as well as safe houses that can be used for recovery by women who have been assaulted.<ref name=DailyNews /><ref name=Guardian /><ref name=EgyptInd2 /> Hotline numbers are passed out on days of major protests. When assaults are reported, requests for help are routed using social media to teams of men and women carrying flares and spare clothing.<ref name=Guardian /><ref name=WeN /> These teams spread out across the square to rescue women as assaults are taking place, particularly during major demonstrations such as the one marking the two-year anniversary of the 2011 revolution on 25 January 2013. Because activists rescuing others are also in danger of assault, OpAntiSH estimates it needs at least 6 groups of 15 volunteers to spread protection across the square.<ref name=EgyptInd2 />
Volunteers in the rescue squads are trained in an approach that has been developed based on the experience of mob assaults in Tahrir and past rescue efforts led by other individuals and groups in the square. OpAntiSH instructs rescuers to keep calm and avoid the use of force if possible, in order to diffuse mobs involved in the attack and minimize trauma to victims. The teams form a human chain around the woman being attacked, a female volunteer moves in to help clothe the victim, and group works together to bring her to safety.<ref name=Guardian /><ref name=Monitor /><ref name=WeN />
OpAntiSH believes that women's participation is important in rescue efforts both to engage with harassers and offer support to victims. “The solution is not just for men to defend us. We, too, have to participate. I believe it’s a women’s fight,” Reem Labib, one of the group's female activists, has said.<ref name=Monitor />
==See also== * [[Egyptian Centre for Women's Rights]] * [[Feminism in Egypt]] * [[Gender inequality in Egypt]] * [[HARASSmap]] * [[Judiciary of Egypt]] * [[Rape in Egypt]] * [[Mass sexual assault in Egypt]] * [[Women in Egypt]] * [[678 (film)]] * [[Alli Arjuna]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.facebook.com/opantish/ OpAntiSH on Facebook]

[[File:Samurai String Quartet Playing at St. Brigid's Centre of the Arts.jpg|thumb|The Samurai String Quartet played covers of 90's grunge music, old Nintendo video games and television theme songs. This particular picture shows them playing "I'm Shipping Off to Boston" by the Dropkick Murphy's. The Quartet played until they were asked to leave at 2 am.]]
[[File:Asphalt.Orchestra.Ottawa.Chamberfest.jpg|thumb|Asphalt Orchestra performing in [[Ottawa's]] Byward Market as part of the Guerrilla Gig series hosted by Ottawa Chamberfest 2011.]]
[[File:Bring the Kids with True North Brass.jpg|thumb|The Bring the Kids event hosted by Ottawa Chamberfest featuring True North Brass. This was the largest Bring the Kids event in the 18 year history of Ottawa Chamberfest.]]
'''Ottawa Chamberfest''' is a [[music festival]] held by the Ottawa Chamber Music Society in [[Ottawa]], [[Canada]]. It will be held between July 26th and August 9th, 2018 marking the start of its 25th anniversary celebration.
==Artists== In 1994, the idea of a chamber music festival in Ottawa came to life to remedy the meager availability of live classical music during the summer months and fill the city’s churches with splendid sounds. Ottawa Chamberfest started life as the Ottawa International Chamber Music Festival with 22 concerts in two churches and was an immediate hit. Growing steadily over the years, the 2011 edition of Ottawa Chamberfest presented almost 100 concerts, attracting over 80,000 listeners and is the largest chamber music festival of its kind in the world.<ref>{{cite web|title=Spotlight on Ottawa Chamberfest|url=http://app01.ottawa.ca/ArtsCalendar/feature.jsf;jsessionid=41617FBC70D973F2DC49AB16D391BF87?lang=&eventId=4201|work=Spotlight - Your Guide to What's Happening|publisher=City of Ottawa|accessdate=May 30, 2011}}</ref>
The members of the Juno award-winning [[Gryphon Trio]] (cellist Roman Borys, violinist Annalee Patipatanakoon and pianist Jamie Parker) are the Artistic Programming Directors for Ottawa Chamberfest.
Among those who performed in the 2011 edition of the festival were [[Jan Lisiecki]], [[Isabel Bayrakdarian]], [[Simone Dinnerstein]], [[Marc-André Hamelin]], Julie Nesrallah, [[Yehonatan Berick]], [[National Arts Centre Orchestra]], [[The Swingle Singers]], [[Nexus (ensemble)]], [[Trio con Brio Copenhagen]], [[New Zealand String Quartet]], TorQ Percussion Quartet and more.
Past performers include Paul Merkelo, Patrick Wedd, Guy Fouquet, Musica Camerata, Stéphane Lemelin, the [[Borodin String Quartet]], the [[Beaux Arts Trio]], the [[Tokyo String Quartet]], [[Martin Beaver]], Penderecki Quartet, [[Paul Stewart (concert pianist)|Paul Stewart]], Martin Chalifour, Monica Whicher, Jennifer Swartz, and [[Gino Quilico]],Quartango, Neil Gripp, Richard Raymond, the [[St. Lawrence Quartet]], Mayumi Seiler, Keller Quartet, and Adaskin String Trio.
==Music== Although the concerts are primarily traditional classical music, the scope has evolved to include music by pop and [[jazz]] [[composers]] and also music from non-European countries. The concerts of a typical day would have several different types of music. For Ottawa Chamberfest 2011, performances are divided into several Concert Series. * Chamber Chat - Lecture series. * Music at Noon - Music at lunch. * New Music Now - Show casing new and emerging artists. * Meet the Artist - Meet several performers up close and personal. * Bring the Kids - Free shows for children. Interactive and fun. * 3PM Series - Afternoon shows * The Siskind Concerts - Nightly shows dedicated to [[Jacob Siskind]], music critic and arts patron. * Market Soirées - Evening Shows with a focus on an intimate musical experience. * Alfresco Concerts and Guerilla Gigs - Free outdoor concerts at Rideau Hall and other undisclosed locations. * Late Night at the Kildare - Hosted by [[Saint Brigid's Church (Ottawa)]], a nightly series featuring a diverse set of performers. * Festival Gala Series - 3 high profile performances at [[Dominion-Chalmers United Church]].
==Venues== The concert venues are generally churches or cultural facilities in the heart of downtown [[Ottawa]]. The confirmed venues for Ottawa Chamberfest 2011 are:<ref>{{cite web|title=Ottawa Chamberfest Venues|url=http://www.ottawachamberfest.com/visitor-info/venues|work=Ottawa Chamberfest|publisher=Ottawa Chamberfest|accessdate=May 30, 2011}}</ref> * [[Dominion-Chalmers United Church]] * [[Rideau Hall]] * [[Beechwood Cemetery]] * [[Saint Brigid's Church (Ottawa)]] * [[Anglican Church of St. John the Evangelist (Ottawa)]]
In previous years the [[University of Ottawa]] was also a regular venue. The Festival has also used, on occasion, Southam Hall in the [[National Arts Centre]] for special gala concerts.
==Other activities== Apart from the annual summer festival, which is the Ottawa Chamber Music Society's major event, the Society also organizes activities throughout the year. The Concert Series takes place from fall to spring offering approximately six concerts per season. There is also the Family Music Fair - a free day of musical activities for all to enjoy. An annual online auction raises money for the Society's operations.

{{Unreferenced|date=February 2009}} A '''paper organization''' is any group which exists more in theory than reality. The term "paper organization" is used in two different contexts, that of the [[military]] and that of the [[labor movement]].
==Military== For the military, a unit which is not combat-ready due to a planned or unplanned lack of men or basic equipment, but which remains in existence on the books, is called a "paper organization." Such a rating of an organization is a regular part of the planning process and the term is not pejorative.
==Political== In the [[trade union]] and [[Political radicalism|radical]] political movements, a "paper organization" is a group ostensibly in existence for a specific purpose, but which remains a phantom. For example, a single individual might claim to represent a non-existing local unit of a national organization in attempt to gain admission as a delegate and thus help "pack" a national convention in favor of a particular [[Political faction|faction]]. Such a phantom unit would be called a "paper organization." Alternatively, the term can be used with regards to a [[single-interest group]] with an impressive name but no greater existence than a [[letterhead]] and a mailing address, and no concrete existence in fact. Some so-called Communist [[front group]]s were an example of this latter form of "paper organization."

page.title: Preventing the lawful burial of a body

revision.text:
'''Prevention of the lawful and decent burial of a dead body''' is an offence under the [[common law]] of the [[United Kingdom]].<ref>{{Halsbury|26|Criminal Law|688|5}}</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/law/2012/jul/18/rausing-charged-unusual-offence "Hans Rausing charged with highly unusual offence" by Daniel Hoadley], ''The Guardian'', Wednesday 18 July 2012</ref> The offence is infrequently charged.<ref>[http://ninetyone.org/policehistory/sources/files/commonlawoffences.pdf Common Law Offences Charged and Reaching a first hearing in Magistrates' Courts], [[Crown Prosecution Service]]</ref> As a common law offence, it is trialable only on indictment and can be punished by a maximum sentence of life imprisonment, an unlimited fine or both.
Examples of conduct amounting to the offence include detaining a body, for instance upon a claim for fees or a debt, refusing to deliver it to the executors for burial, or when entrusted with it for burial selling for dissection. It is a separate common law offence to [[Disposal of a corpse with intent to obstruct or prevent a coroner's inquest|dispose of a dead body with intent to obstruct or prevent a coroner's inquest]].<ref name=Halsbury1104>{{Halsbury|24|Cremation and Burial|1104|5}}</ref>
Burning a body instead of burying it was not illegal.<ref name=Halsbury1104/> It is now an offence to burn a body otherwise than in an approved [[crematorium]].<ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2008/2841/regulation/13/made regulation 13, Cremation (England and Wales) Regulations 2008]</ref>
Disposing of the dead body of a child with intent to conceal the birth of that child (regardless as to when he or she died) is an offence under section 60 of the [[Offences Against the Person Act 1861]].<ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/24-25/100/section/60 section 60, Offences Against the Person Act 1861]</ref>
==Recent cases== [[Hans Kristian Rausing]], heir to [[Hans Rausing]] who owns the multinational food packaging and processing company [[Tetra Pak]], was charged with the offence of preventing the lawful and decent burial of a body on 17 July 2012 following the discovery of the corpse of his wife, [[Eva Rausing]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Eva Rausing death: Husband charged with burial delay|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-18880965|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=17 July 2012}}</ref> He received a suspended sentence of imprisonment.
Nathan Matthews and his girlfriend, Shauna Hoare were also charged with this offence after murdering [[Murder of Becky Watts|Becky Watts]].
==References== {{reflist}}
